posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9524009
When it comes to hours of gameplay in a game, so many people focus on quantity. For me, the quality of those hours is far more important. SMW may only be 10 hours long, but that's 10 hours of good fun. I'll take 10 hours of fun over 100 hours of tedium any day. When I'm done with SMW, I'll move on to another short-but-fun game. I'm no longer a child that has to make the one game I get at Christmas last all year. I'm absolutely swimming in games these days, as I'm sure everyone here is. I don't need to squeeze 100+ hours out of a single game anymore.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Dead or Alive 1
Use the Model 2 emulator.
>Dead or Alive 2
Use the Naomi emulator of your choice, whatever works for you.
In both cases, when MAME doesn't work you have to look around for a stand-alone emulator for whatever platform that arcade game was on. If it was basically a PC, then you use Teknoparrot or jconfig or w/e to act as a wrapper to make the game work on your PC. If it wasn't a PC under the hood, and there is no stand-alone emulator for the platform, and MAME doesn't run it, then you are shit outta luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My recommendations for order play through and platform.

1. RE 96 or Directors cut (non-dual shock) PS1 on CRT
2. RE2 '98 PS1 or DC on CRT
3 RE3 '99 PS1 or DC on CRT
4. CODE VERONICA X (GCN or "PS2 Classic" version on PS4, stay away from the PS2 version and the HD MT Framework versions)
5. REmake PC or GCN + CRT
6. RE0 PC or GCN + CRT
7. Biohazard Outbreak Files 1+2 w/English patch on pscx2 with online via the outbreak resurrection server
8. RE4 PC + HD mod or GCN on CRT
9. RE5 GOLD PC
10. Revelations 1+2 PC
11. RE6 PC
12. RE7 GOLD PC
14. RE8 GOLD PC

Gits and shiggles if you really enjoy the series:
Umbrella Chronicles/Darkside Chronicles on Wii/Dolphin, Gun Survivor 2 w/ light gun or mouse

If you are a completionist:
RE Gaiden GBC and Gun Survivor JPN w/ lightgun

>>9515965
Fair enough, but the way some stuff is being shown in Retrotech videos is misleading at best. I'm not saying he's doing it in bad faith, it's just that the way it's sold can induce unecessary panic in people that don't know better. And if they decide to then recap a set based on that, they'll often end up creating a problem rather than fixing one.

I think he has a lot of very useful practical knowledge about fixing CRTs, but he should know when he's out of his depth on technical matters and just flat out tell people: "look, I'm not exactly sure about this but this is what I think is going on" or something along those lines. He clearly lacks knowledge about some of the details of how the electronic circuitry actually works. There's no shame in that, just be honest.

>>9516704
You can clean mold off VHS tapes. Open top case of VCR. Fast forward the tape. As its running, lightly press Qtip dipped in rubbing alcohol against the capstan so the tape runs across it. Cleans all the mold off. I've done it several times and saved some rare tapes this way.

>Anyway, the brightness issue must be due to the cord.
Without a doubt. PAL/NTSC cable mismatch with consoles will cause that. I don't know the technical reasons, but it's something to do with there being different resistors and capacitors on the chroma and luma lines in the s-video cable depending on signal it expects.

More likely PAL
PAL Nintendo AV cables have a capacitor inside them which darkens the image if used on a NTSC console

posts.com:
- CRTs are no longer produced because they have inferior picture quality versus LCDs
- CRTs emit dangerous levels of X-rays or other forms of radiation
- CRTs always have easily-visible flicker
- CRTs always cause eyestrain
- CRTs always make a high-pitched squealing noise
- CRTs contain lethal amounts of electricity, even when unplugged
- CRTs need calibration more than two to three times a year
- Overall CRT black levels are not superior to LCDs because ambient light ruins CRT black levels
- Analog CRTs have more processing time than digital LCDs due to poor RAMDAC performance
- Afterimages caused by phosphor decay are extremely annoying and are a significant downside of CRTs
- Sending an improper mode (resolution or refresh rate) to a CRT can cause permanent damage
- CRTs cannot have touchscreens
- 4:3 is so bad that nobody should use a non-widescreen CRT
- The Sony GDM-FW900 is the only CRT worth owning
- Curved CRTs have objectively inferior picture quality versus flat CRTs with otherwise equal specifications
- CRTs should not be used because they are heavier and deeper than LCDs
- CRTs have severe reflections because they do not have matte coats
- CRTs can be permanently damaged by nearby magnets
- You will not have sex in 2023
- Analog signals limit a CRT's resolutions and refresh rates and negatively effect picture quality
- Heavy metals are used in CRT glass to reduce radiation

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9523335
DOOM came so very close to the first one. They could have given the pistol perfect accuracy and given a damage boost so every shot does the equivalent of two chaingun rounds, this would give it the functionality of a long range sniper weapon but not overpowered. I would also remove the chainguns perfect accuracy of its first two shots. To balance out the shotgun/super shotgun I would make shotgun ammo way more scarce so having to choose between power and conserving ammo is an actual choice, as it stands in the base game I can just unload a super shotgun blast on lone pistol zombie and not care at all.

For the energy weapons I would bump up the BFGs ammo consumption to 75 or 100 per blast because I never felt the need to use the plasma rifle once I had the BFG as the ammo saved was insignificant especially compared the the time to kill difference between the two. Rocket launcher is perfect as is but it always bothered me that rockets were the only weapon type that only had one weapon, I would add a grenade launcher. A flamethrower would also be nice for damage over time, a nice contrast to the BFG where you have to be looking at the enemy to damage them. For a second flame weapon I would add a three round burst fire flaming stake gun whose bullets would stick into the enemy then explode after a few seconds similar to the needler from halo.

I promised it would be out in 2022, and here it is - a public testing release of Temporal Tantrum for /vr/ only, before a wider release later.

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WJp8h9SZ2AtOJdnP_82h1qnjJnI2Pfs4/view?usp=sharing

Featuring 28 brand new maps across seven different episodes from:
>Washing Machine Enthusiasts (14 maps)
>Lunch Lunch (7 maps)
>Enraged Eggplant (5 maps)
>Bartekmil (1 map)
>Brxyz (1 map)

Also including five custom enemies, some MBF21 shenanigans, some non-Euclidean chicanery, and more besides.

As this is a gamma release (one step up from a beta) everything is there and should work (including full difficulty level implementation), but there could be rough patches - please give feedback for what can be improved. At a minimum, I intend to redo parts of Episode 4 with the 94 Protons tropical plant sprites, and improve the visuals in some maps generally.

As fun as drama is, the reason it's late is because, up until earlier this year, it was basically just me (WME), Eggplant and Lunch mapping for it, then Eggplant & Lunch ran out of ideas and/or motivation. That's not meant as a knock against them, just what happened - it happens to all of us.

Anyway, I (perhaps selfishly) decided to get the project up to four maps per episode singlehandedly (except for a contribution by Bartekmil that he worked on during that time as well) rather than release it as it was, and I did that despite having way too much else going on in my life to dedicate much time to it, so it took the rest of this year to finish the remaining maps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9526138
BFG also is perfectly ammo-efficient on the first shot, dealing exactly 2400 damage for 60 cells (40 per cell). Technically the plasmagun can deal 12, 24, 36, or 48 damage per shot, which averages out to 30 per shot, but you can break it down much more efficiently because one trigger pull is one cell and you don't need to shoot 60 at once. Also if you get lucky you get higher efficiencies, sometimes exceeding the BFG, but not often.
When talking about multiple targets, the BFG loses damage because it splits it damage into groups of 60 (up to 40 projectiles, each dealing Nd60 damage calculated to either kill their target or use up as much of the remaining damage as possible), so anything with health that isn't a multiple of 60 ends up wasting a bit of ammo. Once again, since the PG deals smaller damage per cell good use of it can be more ammo efficient. Definitely can't match the sheer killing speed though.
>math n sheit

>>9526162
Fuggin brain is fried lmao
>perfectly ammo-efficient on the first shot
*against a target that it can't kill in one shot like a cyberdemon
>Nd60
I meant 60*N
Basically the whole cell "economy" is a bit more even for the PG if you aren't trying to explode whole rooms at once. Similar thing with the chaingun where it always hits 15 but the other bullet weapons have slightly different numbers based on role. If you can manage the CG's absurd fire rate you can reach ammo efficiencies that are second only to the pistol's hypothetical max, but it's really inaccurate and you will waste ammo in some cases so it balances out with the SMG which is highly accurate and fires easily controllable bursts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9526138
The alt-fire of the flare gun is super underrated. It's like the equivalent of being able to shoot a rocket out of the doom pistol for 10 ammo. If you come upon a group of enemies let one of those fly, great way to conserve rocket ammo if you're low and you get a similar outcome. Also I think the cultists have a 100% or close to it stun chance if they get hit, so the tommy gun is extremely good against them due to its high fire rate. I remember the plasma gun being great against the hellhounds, was my go to weapon against that enemy type every time.

Blood is a fantastic FPS once you take the time to understand as much as you can about it (like how jumping and crouching makes hitscanners less accurate, or how you should be bouncing explosives around every suspicious corner, they give you tons of dynamite ammo for a reason). I see alot of people give the game a try, get absolutely wrecked by cultists and give up, but if they just knew a little bit more they would be having a total blast. It's sad.

>>9525483
>Can someone explain to me why source code matters
If you have the source code, the nuts and bolts of how a video game is made, you can potentially create really good modding or editing tools to add on to the game. You can already do with games that don't have publicly available source codes, but with the meat and potatoes of it the possibilities are an order of magnitude greater, including the end-user possibly creating their own game with that code. This has already happened with things like Doom's source code, Quake's source code, etc. On the flipside, sometimes source codes get released (legally or otherwise) and nothing really happens because people don't care enough.
>Why don't we already have it?
Developer, software, and publisher rights. Let's say Ed Boon was the sole owner of the source code of MKII. If it was never released, it's because he didn't want it released. But let's say Ed Boon doesn't own it and the parent company to Netherealm Studios owns the MKII source code. If Ed Boon WANTED the MKII source code out there, he'd have to go through corporate, who could just say no since he doesn't own it. If he did it anyway, he could get sued into the ground.
>Have the games not been downloaded and emulated. Are we not able to see the code then, or hack it? Why not?
All source code is converted into machine code so the computer can read it. That means only the truly adept can reverse engineer a video game, and this has happened more than once.

You didn't ask but I feel like video game studios/publishers should just release source codes far more often than they do. Croteam, the developers of Serious Sam, released the source code for Serious Sam 1's engine for free. But that was in 2017 or so, so literally who the fuck cared anymore besides serious Serious Sam fanboys? Unity, Unreal, Godot, etc. have all taken off. If Croteam had released SE1 back in 2003 after The Secound Encounter came out the FPS landscape might have been different.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9529338
Why DO all the characters in MK (visually) have the same normals anyway? In a game with traditional graphics they'd have characters with the same moves and similar outfits to save on labor by editing one character to create the other (draw a Ryu sprite then change the head and colors to make it Ken, many such cases). But in MK they weren't drawing anything, they were just filming actors on a blue screen, so they could have had them all do different moves and it wouldn't have been any more work. They threw away visual variety that they could have had for free.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525483
The ROM image contains "low level" machine code that is run directly on the CPU. Programmers write in a highly level code, like C (higher level languages you may have heard of are C#, JavaScript, Python, Java, etc., but old school arcade games never used these as they needed to be more optimised for performance) school, which goes through a "compilation" process to turn it into machine code. The code written by the programmer is the source code, and you can't directly extract this from the compiled machine code. Writing in Assembly is as close to machine code as you can get, but even then, there are comments in the file and descriptive names for variables that are lost in the compilation process. Decompilation projects manually review all the compiled code and try to recreate what they think the source code would have looked like before it was compiled. This can be verified, to a degree, by compiling the manually decompiled code and seeing if it matches the ROM, but all the identifier names and any programmer comments cannot be derived from the ROM image.

Otherwise if you're trying to emulate shit like PS2 etc, just use standalone emulators on Windows. More times than not, the better performance is on Windoze as much as it kills me as more of a Linux guy myself.

Anyway, hope that taught you how to fish and not be a lazy fuck. It really is just a search away sometimes. It's not programin, it's literally just Vidya game consuming. More often, some retard has had the same problem then you.

You just have to look.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hear me out... This was an experiment, and I think it went well.
I heard the Family Pocket was a fun and convenient device for the money and I thought "bullshit" but tried it because I was looking for cheaper gifts at the time and didn't want to setup and/or build a new device for the 50th time. It's not fun anymore.
I did take out the decoy cartridge and I did throw some other games on to test these silly Java emulators for NeoGeo and SNES, but that's it.
Metal Slug doesn't work. It won't pass the Yoshi's Island test, but I played Earthbound and Mario All Stars fine. Every GBC I've tried ran fine. All the NES and Genesis so far run fine.

It's all setup out of the box with a functioning UI in English, decent lists with boxart, easy save slot for each game, and instant on/off that (so far) seems to be about as safe as possible. I didn't swap the loaded SD for a better one yet so who knows? But six months of testing so far and no worries. I paid $25 for it. It looks and feels like a pickup and play toy and it is. Which I love.

I have several anbernic devices and so on, I'm not a pleb. I'm just sharing my findings on this. It's a really neat convenient affordable toy if you like the proposition.

(Also on a personal note, I love the sound. It isn't good although it has a vol wheel. But the mostly empty softer plastic case seems to smooth out all the bumpy squares and triangles in the sound waves of 8-16 bit games that make my ears thump uncomfortably without a great setup. I have this issue on my 351p with all settings possible tweaked. The smoothing resonance of the cheap case is a nice bonus for me.)
Thank you for liking and subscribing to my autistic review bastard blog

Pre-Retro Era:

Retro Era AKA The Golden Age:
Gen 3 (8 Bit) - NES, Gameboy, Gameboy Color, Master System, Game Gear, PC 88, MSX, ZX Spectrum, Pico-8, TIC-80
Gen 4 (16 bit) - SNES, GBA, Genesis, PC98, TG16, Amiga, Neo Geo
Gen 4.5 - Sega 32X, 3DO, PC-FX
Gen 5 (32 bit 2D + Low Poly 3D) - PS1, Saturn, N64, DS
Gen 5.5 - Dreamcast, PSP, 3DS
Gen 6 (Mid Poly) - PS2, Gamecube, Wii

Eh, agree mostly, but instead of strict gens, i think its important to have a look at major points in history. Like say a late 80s period extending a bit into the early 90s would be the main lifespan of the nes, but you had something like the Amiga 500 also released in 85 which many consider 4th generation comparable if anything, but of that era of the nes, you could find games for it right along the ST, Master System, C64 and Spectrum. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9527620
>story mode
Literally the worst way to get better. The computer is gonna beat your ass before you learn anything because it can literally cheat (instant charge moves, instant dizzy escape, frame perfect inputs), and you're gonna get reckless looking for any openings you can get which will lead to bad habits and sloppy play.
Want to get better? 2P mode solo and beat up on the dummy 2P until you learn some basic combo strings (ex. Guiles bread and butter is Jump HP, down MP, flash kick). If you're too lazy to experiment look up combos for SF II Hyper Fighting' which is what snes turbo is based on. Play against other people.

tldr: playing the computer doesn't make you a good fighting game player.

posts.com:
The computer literally cheats and does shit like read inputs. Fighting them doesnt make you better at fighting people and can even give you some bad habits. It’s only good for seeing the story, but at least you’ll have learned some character’s attacks by now.

Older fighting games are harder to play, timings for combos and specials are way stricter. The ‘beginning’ of the genre is literally harder to play, especially since lots of games have slightly different strict timings.

If you want to get good at old fighting games, download fightcade, look up tutorial and advice videos, and play people.

Other anons will greentext me for recommending discord, but joining the discord group for a game will give you access to tons of players you can ask for game specific advice from. There’s a lot of dumb shit in games it’s better to just be told about than trying to figure out on your own. Someone on one of those discords can also give you the fightcade json autodownloader so you dont have to bother finding roms, definitely recommend asking around for it.

Oh and be a tier whore at least when you start out learning a game. You can always switch characters later, but finding the easiest high tier to play is the best way to learn the ropes of a game.

If you play a charge character, you can hold diagonal down back to charge both your back move-forward move and down-up move at the same time.

>>9527937
Not him but I'll try to explain since they're not wrong. Basically at high level fighters are almost all about mind games. Trying to second guess what your opponent is going to do so you can counter them. When you play against AI you build the muscle memory for doing moves and combos, but you don't build the mind games part because the computer doesn't fight the way humans do. So the longer you play, the more you get used to predicting and countering the AI. It's still an okay starting point but puts you at a distinct disadvantage when you move to fighting people.

So it's not like you can't get good at all playing the computer, but you'll get good much faster playing real opponents. And fighting people should be the goal always because it's where the real fun of the genre lays.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518542
>>9518605
Decompiling is a pain, and usually, you will need to sort out a lot of things by yourself.
Even if decompilers now can separate code from data (which is helped in consoles starting at PS1 gen because some sort of memory formatting was common) you will likely end up with assembly with variable and functions name meaning nothing.
Well, at least, I tried it for the game boy, and so it was.
I don't see why PS1 would be different (except maybe if they let the debug symbols on the final CD? That's not unheard of, but quite rare).

Anyways, good luck, and enjoy your project!
It you can post your advancements here, that would be really great.

What game do you want to decompile?

>https://tetracorp.github.io/tokimeki-memorial/methods/decompiling-psx-games.html
>https://www.reddit.com/r/REGames/comments/lkbzei/how_to_get_started_decompiling_psx_games/ (I know, Reddit, but, hey, this is sensible for once.)

When tackling a decompilation project, you also need to think about which release to tackle.

There's the Japanese version called Magical Hoppers for example. Although it has a different visual appearance, the core game is the same, but there could be other significant changes like refactored program or bug fixes.
There was also a Platinum US release a year later, so that might have the same fixes.
All depends on what they produced and what dumps are available really.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9520325
The Jetsons Invasion of the Planet Pirates comes to mind.
As a licensed game developed by Taito for the SNES, they re-used the game engine and level designs for another licensed game in Japan; Youkai Buster: Ruka no Daibouken.

The game is mostly the same, but the key differences aside from the change in characters and visuals, is a different intro cutscene, the introduction of bonus levels after each action level's boss fight, a whole new final boss, and the inclusion of additional cheat codes whilst the game is paused. The game is however two levels shorter, not all levels were converted from the original game, but some mini-game segments were put in their place.

Whichever version you play though, it is a genuinely good game, nothing amazing, but worth a play.

An overenthusiastic employee made a bunch of ridiculously difficult mazes for the game. They used them in the game just because they didn't want to hurt his feelings. Recognizing that the mazes are, in fact, ridiculous, they included a full guide with the game.
You can go through and draw maps of all the dungeons. This is how I like to do it. It's a kind of challenge that doesn't exist in RPGs anymore. For patient people, it's fun.
Or you can skip all that trouble and use the maps that were included with the game. It's still fun, although there is a bit of grinding. I kind of like the grinding.

I've been doing this somewhat regularly for about a decade now. I had a few attempts at a single "game notes" book, but that has never materialized. One had loads of notes in it, but I left that with a previous relationship. One of my fondest memories was making maps of the crazy MOTHER / EarthBound Zero factories. The music in these games really burns into your brain permanently, and shapes how you feel. It is super cool to go back and reference old notes, though, on repeated playthroughs. posts.com: Osomatsu-kun: Hachamecha Gekijou was one of four Mega Drive launch titles in late 1988 and the only one to not get an international release. Based on the Hachamecha Gekijou anime, which had just been rebooted from an original 1960s run in similar fashion to Q*Taro, another '60s anime/manga that was revived in the '80s and got a video game adaption on the Famicom--Hachamecha Gekijou, like Q*Taro, is not much known outside Japan and has never been dubbed or translated into other languages.. Control Osomatsu, the eldest of the six Matsuno siblings, on a quest to recover his kidnapped brothers from various wacky enemies. What was meant to be a technical showpiece for the new console however ended up being a little less than planned. Sega intended for Osomatsu-kun to use a 4 megabit cartridge but ROM shortages forced them to use only 2 megabits so some levels and other planned features were omitted.

Blaster Master: Blasting Again was such a strange game, I have a theory on that.
>BA was initially planned to be a legit Metafight sequel in Japan.
>Sunsoft realizes they should rewrite the game for the west to fit the old BM canon.
>As a cost-saving measure, Sunsoft decides mid-development to make one script so they don't have to worry about regional differences too much and pay voice actors twice (note Jap BA uses Eng voices with subs).
>Older Kane becomes older Jason but they don't want any existing assets to go to waste and scramble with what to do about the older Jennifer they designed.
>Someone (probably from the American branch) chimes in that there is an equivalent usable female character in the BM continuity that they can use in her place.
>Older Jennifer is rewritten as an older Eve.
>By the time younger Eve was designed for BMZero Sunsoft had completely forgotten that she was ever supposed to be a redhead.
No particular evidence of this, just gut feeling.

Why does DOS MIDI have such a distinctive tone compared to Windows or General MIDI?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525067
MIDI is not a sound or sample set, it is a protocol by which messages are sent to an instrument to command it what note to play, for what duration, etc. A lot of DOS games were programmed with earlier sound chips in mind that used digital FM synthesis, but the Windows sound set is derived from Roland's MT series library, I believe. Sound cards of the 1990s used ROM to perform higher-quality samples, as opposed to synthesis alone.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9526373
If you think about the game's concepts less how they're literally incorporated into the game with 1980s FDS software and more the overall game flow and hallmarks, I think Zelda 2 is definitely a precursor to the type of game that would eventually result in Skyrim
Because it's Zelda there are many streamlined elements, but it's still an expansive action RPG featuring a worldwide trek, exploring dungeons and powering up over time until you eventually rule over the once treacherous world thanks to your new weapons and abilities.
Just to tie in some things that are directly shared between Zelda 2 and Skyrim:
>overall game flow of walk around somewhat empty overworld, finding little caves as well as larger ones and dungeons that you either find goodies in or battle through, often beset on the overworld by roaming enemies, visiting towns to rest up and take in lore while making story progress
>both feature EXP and RPG mechanics that provide the player with plenty of opportunity throughout the game to customize their loadout and decide which stats they'd like to specialize in
>although Zelda 2 lacks most economy and loot systems due to streamlining, its palaces are still quite similar to plenty of Skyrim dungeon areas with many monsters to fight as you comb through the rooms looking for the reward (the ability to place the crystal and level up instantly in the case of Zelda 2)
This is just scratching the surface, basically just pointing out the most obvious shit. I could go on but my point is that Zelda 2's flow reminds me of the type of thing you'd see in many action RPGs to come. It's a game that feels ahead of its time in my opinion for combining those aspects of gameplay in the way it did.

All this said, Im not saying its bad, just re-affirming, if it wasn't zelda, it'd be talked about a lot less and still have all these issues.

Dolphin is a great example of an interface that actually needs to incorporate gamepad controls. There's no reason I need to use a mouse to select a game to play. There's no reason there's hotkeys like the screenshot or pause emulation button that have to be on keyboard instead of gamepad. Some gamepads even have mouse control built in, meaning if Dolphin had a proper console interface in the console emulation software, you'd only need a gamepad to have full control over it.

Retroarch does it correctly, as it is actually control agnostic insofar as an emulator can be. Since you're supposed to play these games on a gamepad, it supports gamepad controls itself. If I'm sitting on the couch, playing on my TV, I should not need to deal with this stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
the breadbin C64 has unreliable, hot-running chips because MOS used an ancient and not very efficient 5-6 micrometer process from the 70s. the VIC-II in particular was quite power-guzzling as it's a very busy chip that has to perform all graphics functions, bus mastering, and RAM refresh, and its internal speed is 8Mhz. after three years of bungled attempts they switched to a modernized lower power 3 micrometer process which is what the C64C chips use.

so combination of some outdated tech and MOS not having especially good engineers.

The hardware is deigned like a 2D system what with it's dedicated sprite and background layers, similar to a SNES or a Genesis except more powerfil. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9524506
Tomb Raider isn't held back by VDP1's fill rate. You can go in and modify the draw commands to draw wireframes instead, which significantly reduces the amount of pixels VDP1 needs to draw and how much fill rate is needed. If you do this however you'll notice the game still chugs and slows down in the exact same spots to the exact same levels of performance. This indicates that VDP1 fillrate is NOT what's causing the performance issues. This means it could either be a CPU bottle neck, memory bottlenecks, etc. Odds are the game just didn't get the final bits of optimization the PS1 port got due to the Saturn port being rushed out sooner.

The other thing to keep in mind is that Sony had their performance analyzer that could tell devs exactly where the bottleneck was in their code and how to fix it. Neither Sega nor Nintendo had anything like that. So that helped developers produce faster code.

So while VDP1's fill rate is lower than the PS1's GPU, it's not the massive performance gap many think it is. Most of these games aren't doing anything that should be getting close to that limit. To hit that limit you need to be doing something really dumb like rendering the entire frame with transparent polygons or not having any code to sort and eliminate non visible polygons.

>>9524798
This is a myth. The PS1 was sold at a similar loss to the Saturn when it launched in 1994 in Japan. This has been revealed by recent interviews from employees involved in both companies. PS1 cost about 50,000 Yen per unit to produce, Saturn cost about 54,800 Yen. Yes Saturn is more, but it's not $100 more. Both systems were sold at a $100 loss as well. The biggest cost issue in both systems wasn't the number of chips, it was the RAM. RAM prices were stupid high during this time and fell dramatically in the next 3 years. What was over $200 worth of RAM in both systems dropped to under $5 worth of RAM in the span of 2-3 years.

People love to point to $399 vs $299 but forget to look at the difference in launch dates. By the time the PS1 launched at $299 Sega had already dropped the Saturn to $349 due to the new VA1 revision and falling RAM prices with it still coming with a game. If you bought a game with your PS1 at launch, you'd be paying the same amount. 2-3 weeks after the PS1 launched Sega released a Saturn that didn't come with a game for $299. By late Spring of 1996 both systems dropped to $199 due to RAM prices continuing to fall dramatically, and in Sega's case more cost reductions with the Model 2 Saturn.

The price wasn't the issue, it was the horrible launch line up in the US.

>>9524640
The Saturn's VDP2 was effectively an entirely separate GPU with dedicated VRAM so a game could offload environments to it and not have to compete with other things for resources in the way the PS1 does.

Something similar happens with visual effects like the water and heat ripples in Mega Man 8 and Mega Man X4. On the Saturn it's a simple VDP2 feature but it's a bit more complicated on PS1 so they just didn't bother. The same way the VDP2 caused problems with transparency layering, it had advantages in other areas.

This is why games were more interesting to compare back then. They were often designed with the system's strengths and weaknesses in mind allowing for more visual diversity. It only became a problem when you started porting shit and suddenly every system looked like a potato. The SNES couldn't handle Genesis ports, either.

His ass. VDP1 is slower than the PS1's GPU, no doubt about that. But 3DO's fillrate is even lower and it's CPU is significantly weaker and slower. Plus it has it's OS that HAS to be loaded in and running which takes up a significant portion of memory and resources.

As for VDP1 vs PS1 GPU, I think the max theoretical fill rates are something like 24 Million Pixels per second for VDP1 vs 33 Million Pixels per second for PS1? For transparencies both will go down, but Saturn takes a very massive hit with them taking 6x longer to render, plus it doesn't work correctly in most scenarios. But for most scenarios it's basically VDP1 has about 2/3 - 3/4 of the fill rate that PS1's GPU has, but there's also VDP2 to help out with background layers and what not. In practice though you generally shouldn't be hitting those limits on either system. And if you look at a lot of these games it's not fill rate that's causing performance issues. It's generally a CPU or Memory bottleneck due to poorly optimized code, bad compilers, or poor usage of CPU and Memory resources.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525101
> it means UP TO 6x, meaning in the worst case scenario, meaning all effects on + transparency, vs no effects on and no transparency.

I literally said that figure applied to rendering transparencies. Gouraud Shading doesn't really have much of a performance hit on VDP1. If you want to know how that figure is actually determined it basically boils down to this.

- A non textured pixel takes about 1 clock cycle to draw.
- A textured pixel takes about 2 cycles to draw.
- A textured and gouraud shaded pixel still takes about 2 cycles to draw.
- A half transparent pixel takes about 6 cycles to draw.

So compared to untextured pixels it's 6 times longer to draw, compared to textured it's 3 times longer to draw. So this is where your up to 6 times longer comes from. So with those values we can say that the max theoretical fillrate of VDP1 is 26-28 Million pixels per second depending on what resolution mode the Saturn is in and if you're drawing all untextured pixels. This is probably how the theoretical value listed earlier was determined. For Textured and Gouraud shaded pixels it's about 13-14 Million pixels per second. For half transparent pixels, it's about 4-5 Million pixels per second.

That's still a pretty significance performance hit for half transparencies. Throw in that they don't work correctly all the time and it's easy to see why most devs went with meshes.

That all said, if you're not doing half transparencies VDP1's fillrate is still more than enough for most games. At 320x240 resolution at 30fps you have enough fillrate to draw the entire frame buffer about 6 times per frame. So if you're sorting and culling polygons properly and not trying to draw everything as half transparent, you really shouldn't be hitting the fillrate limit.

>>9525162
iirc vdp1 requires 1 cycle to prepare a pixel and 1 to write, so nontextured pixel is 2 cycles and textured is 3. half transparency is 6. gouraud shading only increases the per-polygon setup time.

>we can say that the max theoretical fillrate of VDP1 is 26-28 Million pixels per second
26/28 mpixels assumes perfect access of memory on every cycle, not possible because the vdp1 uses sdram, and you have to deal with page miss penalties.

The real peak fillrate is ~24 mpixels peak. early docs flat out state this number. there's at least one homebrew app that measures this same speed on the sh2 side which also uses sdram.

one of the docs gives an actual figure you can use for approximating both texture drawing time, vdp1 per-polygon setup, and page miss penalties. i don't remember the exact values but you could only hit two digit practical fillrates if you did zero effects. with textures, you can barely fill a 320x224 framebuffer twice before you drop out from 60fps.

>>9523968
It's GPU was essentially a 2D GPU, the very way textures and their polygons worked was an extension of just applying transform effects to sprites. This is why they used quads instead of triangles, since a sprite is a flat image that has 4 corners. They essentially hacked up 2D GPU techniques with enough transform effects to make it kinda sorta work like a 3D GPU. The quads was a major reason why the Saturn could not do transparency effects except for sprites.

>>9523983
>>9523993
Bull. While the PS1 lacked a Z-buffer, it's GPU actually rendered in a 3D plane and was made for realtime 3D, it didn't hack up sprites to the point that you were using them in place of textures because you could apply enough transform effects to them to make them kinda sorta work as 3D polygons.

Yes, everything rasterizes the final image onto a 2D screen, that does not mean "every system is 2D", it's rasterizing a 3D image to a 2D screen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9528623
The Sega CD came out in 1991, way too early for it to factor into anything Saturn related. A scenario where the Sega CD had a better VDP that could push more colors than the base Genesis though, that would have made a giant difference. Instead of being a middling success the Sega CD would probably have carried the Genesis for much longer. That wasn't really possible though because of the way the expansion port worked.

Besides, the Saturn was arguably already too early as is. You wouldnt want it out before late 1994 since the technology of the 90s kept advancing every few months. It's why all those early attempts at launching the next gen, like the Jaguar and 3DO look so hilariously underpowered compared to the PS1 and N64 despite technically being direct competitors. The Saturn needed some more time to cook, not less.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9528636
A CD can store higher quality textures compared to what you could fit onto a cartridge but that's more or less it when it comes to in-game graphics. A CD won't help you push more polygons or anything and you're still limited primarily by the system's RAM. The N64's unified RAM architecture is probably what hurt it the most. It was obviously a cost cutting measure but back then you really needed dedicated VRAM.

The 32x and CD were bad business decisions regardless of power or their design, consumers just don't respond well to upgrading their consoles with add ons. The best you can do is milk more money from your existing install base, and it damages confidence in your brand when consumers don't trust that they'll be able to play subsequent releases on the console they've already bought without first forking out extra cash on an upgrade. Regardless of release dates etc there's a big opportunity cost in putting your r & d resources into add-ons.

>>9529169
Not doubting that but that's exactly the problem. If you ask people what they want from a new system in 1992 then you're going to get very different answers compared to asking that same question in 1994. Sega didn't really do anything "wrong" with the Saturn's hardware. They started building a system based on needs that were current at the time. Then suddenly the market shifted and 3D started overtaking the landscape and so they'd either have to scrap the entire thing and start over or build on the engineering work that was already done in order to catch up to the trends. The extreme other end of the spectrum is something like the PC-FX, which barely was able to do anything relevant to the mid-90s and completely tanked because of it.

I've seen people insist 2 isn't just mash X to win and your magic is good, but it felt like they streamlined melee attacks but not magic so you either mash X and do a ton of damage or you entirely break your flow to cast a couple spells that do next to nothing. I ended up dropping 2 because the combat just wasn't very interesting to me and the amount of cutscenes was just frustrating with how often it took control away from you. KH1 has got the most perfect pacing when it comes to gameplay progression and powercreep

Sora starts with very simple movement and his attacks are very simple, by the end once you face off the extra bosses you really feel like you have grown as a character specially if you craft all end game weapons for all 3, many games fail at recreating this feel and it's very rewarding

Having said that though I think I like KH2 for completely different reasons, it being a pseudo Devil May Cry with JRPG elements being one of them, also KH2 is more "anime" than KH1 because of all the 1v1 fights and all the cool shit Nomura included in many of the bosses and general gameplay

I was 10 when this came out. This shit was mindblowing to a kid. I grew up with Disney cartoons and FF7 was one of the first games I had on PS1. The commercial with simple and clean would play all the time. Yeah this shit was dope, what a time to be alive.
Thankfully I wasn’t super autistic, but the wave of autism this caused at some kids in school was immense (I am thinking about one annoying retard in particular).
Sequel was good too but wasn’t nearly as magical, mostly liked it for Tron world.

My favorite thing about this game was how it starts you off on this ethereal comfy island with all your friends (who are kid versions of characters from final fantasy games you already played) and then it transports you to fucking Disney animated universe with movies you already watched. It was so weird and interesting, and I really like how they did the 2D Disney cartoons in 3D without losing much in translation.
Embarrassing to admit to liking something so autistic but holy shit this was a drug to a child in 2002.
It lives and dies by its incredible opening, that tropical island as your door to a new universe was expertly done.

>>9526446
Animation, sound, art design, level design/variety are all top-notch. Boss design is great and plenty of enemy variety. Primary and secondary weapons are well-balanced and there is a trade-off between more firepower vs. higher rank.

What I really love though is the slower, more deliberate approach to the game. I think that's what a lot of people struggle with, this is a game where you are really meant to proceed with caution and really take advantage of the fact that the game doesn't autoscroll. Every time you play, you get a bit more efficiency, a bit better method to approach a section, and can better parse the vast amount of information that is thrown at you at once. And then when you start to get really good, you can do speed strats (unfortunately there is no scoring incentive, but still fun). It's definitely a game that grows on you.

For emulation, I've been trying to find out what methods can be used for widescreen, without pop-in, culling, or other major issues. I was hoping you could help.

Let's start with dreamcast. The following games support 16:9 native (anamorphic):
Donald Duck Quakers, Rayman 2, Tokyo Xtreme Racer 2, Toy Commander, Toy Racer.

The following work in redream with the widescreen hack setting:
Crazy Taxy 2, Cyber Troopers Virtual On 2, DOA 2, Dolphin Blue, Fighting vipers 2, Ikaruga, MvC 2, Power Stone 2, Resident Evil Code Veronica X, Shenmue 1&2, Skies of Arcadia, Sonic Adventure 1&2.

The following work in Flycast, might work in redream, not sure:
Border Down, Cannon Spike, Carrier, Chaos Field, Charge 'N Blast, Chu Chu Rocket, Cosmic Smash, Crazy Taxy, D2, Death Crimson OX, Draconus, Dynamite Cop, Head Hunter, Heavy Metal Geomatrix, Illbleed, Karous, Maken X, Millennium Racer, Outrigger, Power Stone 1, Project justice, Rainbow Cotton, Red Dog, Re-Volt, Rez, Sega GT, Soul Calibur 1, Soul Reaver, Spawn Demon's Hand, Star Wars Racer, Super Magnetic Neo, Sword of Berserk, Time Stalkers, Virtua Fighter 3tb, Virtua Tennis 2, Wetrix, Zero Gunner 2, Zombie Revenge, Zusar Vasar

Does not work properly in widescreen:
Bangai-O, Capcom vs SNK 2, Confidential Mission, Frame Gride, Gundam Side Story Ashes, Jet Grind Radio, Napple Tale, Silent Scope, Slave Zero, Tomb Raider 4 Revelation & 5 Chronicles, Virtua Tennis 1

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
2 is impressive for how much they were able to do with a snes rpg but it’s quite rough around the edges, even compared to other games of that time. The upside is you can get right into the action pretty quickly. If you play it, be sure to use the fan retranslation and maybe the hack that lowers the encounter rate.
3 is great, definitely the best if you stick with it but it takes a very long time for the game to pick up. The first 10-15 hours are basically just a prologue.
4 is memorable for its art style and some of the twists, but, taken as a whole, it’s not quite as good as 3. Also the English release had some content removed but the Japanese version has an English patch.

2 or 3 should probably be considered the best, depending of your taste.
4 looks fantastic but it's a bit controversial. Some love it, and some hate it.
Dragon Quarter is very controversial, and it's the only one that isn't a "basic" RPG (nothing wrong with that, by the way). It's a masterpiece, but very strange gameplaywise. It's the kind of game that would have been better received by players 15 years later, and it didn't help that hardcore fans hated it. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Adventures of Batman and Robin on the SNES was my favorite as a kid. I loved the show so much and this game had such perfectly faithful presentation that it felt like playing the show itself. Each stage began with a title card in the same style as the ones in the show, followed by a cutscene and dialogue with Alfred setting up a mission. Pretty much every major villain was in the game and there were bits of dialogue with them too. You had a bunch of gadgets to use and there was some variety to the stages too so it actually felt like playing as Batman and not like a generic beat-em-up or run-and-gun with a coat of paint like a lot of superhero games at the time were. Pretty much a perfect adaptation as far as I'm concerned, the only flaw was being single player only.

>>9527536
I was fond of Death & Return as a kid for a similar reason as above, it was a direct and faithful adaptation of a storyline from the comics. They even reproduced panels from the comic as cutscenes which was really neat to see. But unfortunately it's really just a repetitive beat-em-up underneath it all.

>>9518520
Which version you want to play is mostly a matter of graphics. Some think the early release is more atmospheric, others prefer the redrawn versions. See pic related.

Either way, make sure to play a version that has the original still screen gameplay instead of freeroam. The still screens were designed around making things you were supposed to find easily visible, so if you play a freeroam version without having played the original first, it's very easy to miss things that were never meant to be hard to find.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518548
It was extremely significant at the time and is an important point on the timeline of how videogames progressed, so if you're interested in that which the people here who aren't just literally autistic and refuse to play anything they haven't played 1000 times before presumably are it's worth playing just for that reason. It's also a 3D art style that existed in the 90s where fidelity was starting to get to where things are recognizable and nice looking but still very artificial, it gives art like this a dreamlike quality and, at least to me, gives a powerful feeling of what the tech world was like generally back then, I can't look at myst without remembering stuff like the transition from dos to windows, the optimism, just that time period in general and I think that would come through even for someone without memories of that time. It's not a terribly exciting game, but it wasn't back then either. Play it to experience what we considered top of the line art and technology back then, don't expect it to be some kind of thrill lol. It's an adventure game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518585
>extremely significant at the time
Yeah, but it was mainly because CD-ROM craze. It sold in absurd numbers, but was it really that influential, besides spawning a ton of imitators? First person adventure games were nothing new, and neither was environmental storytelling. Without that, Myst only has graphics. I guess you can say that modern walking sims lifted the storytelling tropes from mystoids, but they didn't do it directly - they evolved by themselves from first person horrors like Amnesia and the particular breed of HL mods.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518646
It literally pioneered pre-rendered graphics and environmental storytelling. You're going to say no its some other retarded obscure game, but yes, it did. It was a popular game that proved that both concepts could be relevant and it is extremely historically important. The way that Myst told its story, along with the manner the world presents things is a massive precursor to many games that would be released after it.

Also, even till this day, when the art is at its best (e.g. Sirrus's rooms) it is beautifully detailed. FYI, I played Myst for the first time this year, so no, I'm not nostalgiaing over it. The game has great design for its time and is a foray not only into environmental storytelling, but storytelling period in games. Just compare the stories of games that came before Myst and you'll see what I mean.

>>9518520
Myst and Myst Masterpiece Edition are identical in content, but Masterpiece has better audio and color depth compared to the original release. Play Masterpiece Edition if you want less dithering. The only version released after Masterpiece Ed that I can recommend is the first remake, RealMyst (2000), Not to be confused with RealMyst: Masterpiece Edition (2014), or Myst (2020). Realmyst has a lot of minor visual inconsistencies with the original game, but I felt that it preserved the visual tone in realtime 3D better than the sort of tacky 2014 version. I haven't played 2020 Myst, but it doesn't look great, and is and even bigger departure than any of the other remakes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9526672
It was always a tech demo
VF1: just its existence was revolutionary, from the system to the models. Hair and cloth physics, even animated faces.
VF2: texture-mapping
VF3: eye-tracking, more dynamic faces, hair and cloth physics expanded upon, uneven stages and dodge button
VF4: first 3DFG with customization and an online service (arcade only), introduced side-stepping, breakable walls, one stage had a snowy floor and another a watery floor
VF5: Ultimate was done in the Dragon engine, but that's all I remember

>>>9526767 (You)
>>saturn
>Arcade version is better I only have the PSN version of it because I started the series a little later


The framerate was one of the big improvements that Virtua Fighter 2 made over Virtua Fighter 1. The first game still looked incredible for a 1993 release, but it is still the slowest playing of the Virtua Fighter series. Kinda like how Street Fighter 1 ran at a low framerate. All of the home ports of Virtua Fighter 1 are locked down to 30fps. The 32x game retains 30fps for the majority of the game, but has some slowdown during the win/ lose cutscenes. One of the big enhancements that the model 2 arcade board made was the 60 (57fps) framerate. Every Model 2 arcade game targeted 57fps. Though the Saturn and many of the home ports (Excluding the Genesis port) run at a slightly higher framerate than the arcade game at a real 60fps.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ojLtum_HYAc

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9526810
>>Though the Saturn and many of the home ports (Excluding the Genesis port) run at a slightly higher framerate than the arcade game at a real 60fps.
>Oh. I still like the arcade one better because the backgrounds are 3D rather than sprites.

The Saturn version is still great, and even has the 2.1 arcade updates. It plays incredibly close to the arcade game. But it is misisng the polygon backgrounds. The Saturn game was also ported to Windows 95 back in the day, and the Windows 95 port looks just like the saturn game, but has the option for D3D rendering and you can use the arcade models instead. I feel like the XBLA port was one of the best versions (It is also on PSN?, but I have never played that one)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NGHJHq0oHw8
This one has the arcade visuals, but runs at a higher resolution than the arcade game, and also 60fps.

The arcade model 2 board does not run at 60fps due to some sort of limitations of the board. It's really 57fps, but when used with the right type of CRT display, you don't really notice. But 57fps would look janky on LED's, so many of the later VF2 home ports are set to 60 for consistencies sake.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9524408
Unfortunately, it's not easily obtainable knowledge, you should know C, you should understand how the compilator processes your code and you should understand the assembly language of a target platform(MIPS in the case of PSX). Tools allow you to decompile an executable file to asm functions with generic names, even convert them to c. But it's not like load exe to Ghidra and getting a working code.

In rare cases, devs forgot the symbol file on a disk so you can obtain names for functions and variables but usually, they don't. So you need to guess names for thousands of functions and variables.

Reverse engineering is a hobby for a high skilled and autistic programmers.

>>9525986
Most Rockstar games are these sequences of arbitrary, barely playable one-off tasks that are ridiculous enough to be entertaining on paper but not too ridiculous for the setting. That's not a dumb way to design your realistic sandbox when missions have good flow and presentation that naturally weave you into these tasks, but that's not what Bully does or even can do. The world doesn't make up for the bad gameplay but is completely dead and eventless until you get to the point where your task or minigame happens, which is either frustrating or way too easy and not worth exercising more than your bare minimum for because you know it's just another cheap one-off thing. They clearly didn't respect the setting of their own game and knew just throwing the GTA principle at a boarding school would be enough for the media and journalists to make it sell. Not even asking for a proper morality system or good NPC AI, but, contrary to what the title promises, you can't even live out your inner bully in this game or do anything too evil

>>9496654
Being poor third-worlders, at school we emulated the everloving shit out of those five games and G/S/C through VBA, usually sharing tips or teams. I played a common save in the library PC during recess with other three guys from my classroom, all doing a bit per day or picking one pokemon for the current team.
To be honest, I went through the 3rd gen games because I liked the new pokemons, it was my entry to 1st gen and I wanted to play more of the franchise, but it always felt like a downgrade to the GBC games; no visible day/night cycle, the gimmicky base building and contests and the music were things I didn't like over the simpler, more dynamic experience from the previous generation. I guess things would have been different if I had played them on the hardware and had traded and battled with other people as it was intended.
If I had to choose, though, it would be Emerald. The Battle Frontier was a great time sinker once you found that one place you liked and went through again and again, in my case being the Factory and renting pokemons.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9498454
If they really wanted to, they'd find a way to make them compatible. even if it just amounted to cloning a copy of the original Pokemon. They had to figure out how to assign genders and shiny status for Gen 1 Pokemon into Gen 2, after all.
Instead they required no less than 4 games to catch all Pokemon that generation.

That said I do find it interesting since I'm willing to five GF the benefit of the doubt that it wasn't just greed like most people, but wanting to do a social experiment where they wanted to see how Pokemon would spread. I think it became more fully realized once online trading became standard, when D/P came out with online trading it was really cool to propagate Pokemon that weren't easy to acquire with the standard D/P games online. stuff like Johto starters or swarming /honey/mansion Pokemon that were rare encounters in game but easy to find in RSE/FR/LG.

>>9498630
I'm talking about something a lot greater than little callbacks or references. I'm talking about having a real plot and a main narrative that gets fleshed out, not reinvented, when Pokemon was brand new and not just another series that everybody knew the "rules" of how the franchise works, a lot of us viewed it differently. We expected our adventure in Gen1 and everything it presented from intriguing Pokemon bios, the cryptic story of Mew/Mewtwo etc, and even things from the anime to be laying the groundwork for some bigger narrative, but it wasn't...and that's where the disappointment lies. I remember being a kid and playing Saphire version and enjoying the gameplay well enough but just thinking "oh, so that's it....we're in a new region and there's a new narrative with new creatures, that really doesn't elaborate on or build off the last and creates its own new semi self contained story/mythology" and it was then I knew that's how Pokemon was going to work as a franchise, and it worked for them, keeping things fairly new each time is part of why it's so successful and easily adopted by each new era of kids, but it still disappointed a lot of us. If you came into Pokemon post Gen 1 when the rules of how Pokemon works as a franchise were established, it's probably hard to imagine a time when nobody knew that and assumed every little tiny detail in Gen 1 was a big deal that had something to do with a greater story

In retrospect, obviously not much thought went into the plot, but it didn't feel that way to us as little kids who took it very seriously

This was easily my favorite generation of Pokemon games. I only played gens 1, 3, 4 and 6 though. I'm sure I missed out on some good stuff with GSC, but I at least played SoulSilver.

I should say that I both understand how FRLG seems like a soulless rehash to many people and personally think it's one of the nicest-looking, best-playing games in the series, if that makes sense. I played Red and Yellow before I played FireRed and honestly don't really prefer one version over the other. I think the original games had better music and a handful of better lines of dialogue, but FRLG was pretty great otherwise. I like held items, natures and all the other gen 3 junk and honestly like being able to play Red or Green with that stuff thrown in. I liked the way the Pokedex was presented and how the game gives you a little recap of what you last did whenever you load a save. The Sevii Islands were boring though, and the battle sprites should have been animated like they were in Emerald.

>>9496654
I actually preferred Ruby/Sapphire because it at least was something new for its time. It did a lot of cool things and to me really freshened up the series up to that point. The only thing it missed was doing the physical/special split for attacks. That came a gen later. Would have been sweet to see it introduced with R/S/E instead. Was probably the most logical change to ever come to this franchise but by the time it showed up I was already done with Pokemon so I never played past the third gen of games. It was also nice to see those secret bases be a thing even if there was only a few limited locations for it. Was nice you could link up with friends, even have your friends character persist in your world. The fashion shows were also a fun divergence from the main game. Something this series desperately needed instead of just constant battling. Also made lesser mons and attacks not always completely worthless. Just too bad it was never expanded on really to my knowledge. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I was in elementary school when Duke 3D came out, but my mom bought it for me anyway.
Playing it at that time and at that age was mindblowing - levels that felt like real, actual places? A main character who drops one liners and comments on events as they happen? The ability to explore by crawling, jumping, and blowing open walls? Of course the big jiggling titties were nice and the swearing was funny, but even more astounding to kid-me was how immersive it felt. Doom had tried to depict locations, but at the end of the day it all felt less like space bases and hell castles, and more like abstract mazes with cool textures on the walls. Don't get me wrong, a lot of Duke's architecture falls apart under even a small amount of scrutiny, but nevertheless you could tell you were in a movie theater, a bar, a sushi restaurant, etc. It even made my little nerd brain think things like "oh wow, what if my doctor's hospital were a Duke level? You could hide behind the counters, run down the halls, fight aliens in the skybridge... It would be perfect!" as I went about my day.
I don't know if I'd even classify Duke 3D as one of my favorite games nowadays, but outside of maybe Pokemon, I can't think of many other games that really impacted me deeply enough to change how I thought about things in my daily life.

Facts about this pin:
Best selling pinball machine of all time. Sold 21070 units.
There was going to be an N64 game from Digital Eclipse that recreated this pinball machine, but it was cancelled in an early stage of development.
Pat Lawlor, this game's designer, retired just this year. His last game, which also came out earlier this year, was Toy Story 4 from Jersey Jack Pinball which sold out quite fast, ending his career on a high note.
The Weather Machine topper you see on top of a lot of Addams Family pins derives from a deleted scene from the movie. Of course, Williams didn't know the scene wasn't going to make the final cut of the movie when they built the topper.
There was a pinball machine based on the Munsters TV show released in 2019.
One of Pat Lawlor's early ideas for the design involved a dollhouse-type diorama in the backbox which would light up and do stuff.

>>9526050
I echo the same sentiment that rings true for many who grew up playing this: he was absolutely TERRIFYING, but ultimately placed the player in an extremely unique position that taught them to overcome fear, and the value of empathy. Like, REAL fear and REAL empathy, that shit had profound impact on a lot of kids.

I like many swam away/turned off the game the first time. However, over the course of slowly working up the courage to approach him, you quickly find out he is good—not only a friend, but he is a victim. Clanker is abjectly suffering. He is literally enslaved and abused, rotting in the decay and neglect of his environment. This is why Clanker is special and unique—you are HORRIFIED of this fucker at first, but this slowly fading feeling of fear intermingles with increasing pity. It teaches children to gain courage through confronting fear, and to not withhold your compassion from people just because they are ugly, or seem off-putting or scary. It doesn't matter if Clanker is a giant metal shark with a face like a nightmare, you STILL need to get in there, be a hero, help alleviate some of the guy's suffering and extend some compassion to the poor fucking creature.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9511906
>>9512063
I'm actually of the opinion that visual novels are better if Japanese isn't your first language.
I've read plenty of English visual novels and the experience can be somewhat unengaging, and they certainly don't feel like video games.
Reading a Japanese VN is much more involved. Looking up words, trying to learn them, and untangling sentences with twisted spaghetti grammar is quite stimulating. It honestly feels like playing a good puzzle game.
Like most puzzle games it can be really frustrating sometimesー I remember nearly pulling my hair out trying to figure out what the fuck 々 meant without knowing how to type or pronounce it. But overall it's mostly fair and mostly fun.
The extra time you spend with the story from your slow reading speed helps you get invested, and all the extra challenges you had to overcome really makes it feel earned when the cute anime girl you've fallen in love with tells you she loves you too.
In any case, ToHeart2 is an interesting title to look into even if you usually couldn't care less about visual novels. The PC version (XRATED) comes with a versus puzzle game and a shooting game, and the third entry Manaka de Ikuno!! comes with a trading card game and a full RPG. They're a lot of fun; it makes me wish more VNs had minigames.
If anyone here is interested in trying out XRATED, make sure you get the latest update, it adds a new character to the puzzle game.

>>9507519
I think this website alone proves that people who are against achievements in video games simply lack skill.

It was only when they were first introduced in the PS3 / 360 era that cheevos sucked. The go-to example of this is probably The First Templar (way too easy) or Gran Turismo 5 (requires a retarded amount of dedication) not to mention all of the online-only trophies which were functionally impossible to get.

Nowadays, while there are a lot of games releasing solely for trophy hunters to get an easy platinum, most other achievement lists are designed by the developers themselves rather than a third party. In my opinion, if retro devs had access to cheevo software back in the day, the lists they would have made might be quite similar to these fanmade ones - barring glitches and 1cc autism, of course.

My go-to pick for proof of why RetroAchievements is fantastic are the coin challenges in SMB1. Even when you consult a level map to get every coin possible, ratchet scrolling means you have to be basically perfect. There's also the ironman challenge for SMW, or the extra hard cheevos for F-Zero X. It's also worth mentioning that the API's implementation is a fantastic training tool for indie devs since you have to dive deep into the code and tinker with lots of stuff just to make a functioning trophy.

There are definitely games which don't need achievements at all. Like, no one is ever going to fucking care you got 100% in NES Bubble Bobble. I still believe that it's a necessary step towards helping the younger generation get into older games. I hated Balloon Fight and Clu Clu Land until I tried getting cheevos for them, and it showed me that in spite of their lack of content these games can be enjoyed for an insane amount of time if you're going for specific challenges.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Many. More people today appreciate Roguelike games than back when Rogue first came out, including retro ones like ADoM. I remember when SimCity 4 first came out, many people complained it was overly difficult to maintain a city and not as enjoyable as 2000 or 3000, now people consider it to be the best in the series. E.T. on the 2600 was considered absolute garbage at the time, now people have read the manual and understand how to play the game it's not considered so bad. Friday the 13th on NES also got left in the weeds, now people consider it a somewhat flawed action game. Starcraft Brood War has more balanced maps, more freedom in map creation, and far more UMS custom maps to play on than it ever has, along with less bugs than it did in the retro days.
Add in mods and hacks, and tens of thousands of retro games can be made better than they ever were. Saving in games that used to use passwords, mods that remove slowdown, mods that fix graphical and text issues, mods that fix bugs and glitches, and so on. Retro videogames are getting better by the day to the point even crappy games like Super Pitfall are getting overhauled into something halfway decent.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The Oracle games are some of the worst the series has produced and I don't understand why anyone considers these better than Link's Awakening. Seasons is the better of the two, but still bland. Ages has a bunch of tedious bullshit that wastes your time, switching eras takes way too long and involves a lot of trial and error since warping to a non-walkable space means you have to warp back and then reposition yourself. Doing this multiple times during every trek across the overworld gets annoying quick since the harp song+warp cutscene can't be skipped. Both have the ring system where you find mystery rings which are appraised at a shop, but they're all so useless you'll forget it's even part of the game. The linked game concept was neat, but most of the items you can get aren't worth the hassle (and the ones that are aren't available for most of the game). The dungeons have rooms larger than the screen, unlike LA, but they do nothing with the extra space. Seasons has a few neat nods to Zelda 1, some of the dungeon layouts and bosses are directly inspired by that game. The story isn't anything special, Link gets sent by the Triforce to two different kingdoms where the Twinrova witches are trying to manipulate the local villains into kidnapping the sages of (game title) so they can light some magic flames to bring back Ganon. Soundtracks are completely forgettable. Graphics are a gross hodgepodge of recolored Link's Awakening assets and hastily made tiles that don't match at all. Special shoutout to the Ages Goron simon says dance mini-game that requires you to match a tempo perfectly on beat with zero sound cues.

AoW seems to be written in Delphi, judging from the .dpl files (they're just dlls btw).
The UI uses the Visual Component Library that is based on Win32 API but adds a lot of custom controls. Looks like it was one of the easiest way to build good looking GUIs in Windows at the time.

As for VNs from that time, maybe they used the Windows API with custom engines in C or C++ or even languages like Hot Soup Processor.
Then engines like KiriKiri and Nscripter got popular.

>>9527356
>don't think I've ever seen a source for that but I've read it in other places. I don't know where the rumor comes from or if it's true.
Right, but it's definitely an idea that's been going around online, true or not. It's a small form of vindication for me at any rate, even finding out that it's definitely untrue would be interesting enough for me.

With some extensive Googling and searching, I found a couple of references to it on TVTropes (unsourced, and who knows when they were added), a brief thread about it on R*ddit from earlier this year, and then some scant few mentions of it in the archives of /vr/ and /v/ dating back the past decade or so.
If it's actually true, potentially the one source is actually in Japanese and it's something that's only been wandering around the western world by word of mouth, and either it was never translated, or the translation of it fell off the web at some point.

What we have to back it is 1, that the claim of the idea has been passed around for a long time (never challenged and never sourced), but of slightly stronger substance, 2, there's some interviews with the devs where they do actually mention that Namco made them change a number of things about the game to tone it down, such as making the zombies less realistic and human looking, making the blood green, etc.
There's no mention about the concept of the player character, but that wouldn't have to mean that it wasn't something which changed during development, regardless of it was something changed in the last minute as often told of, or if it was something which was proposed but nixed early on. The player initially being proposed as an evil killer looking to murder a poor girl, then being changed into a hero trying to save his girl would be going from a darker to a lighter tone, and it would make the fact that the player looks like a famous slasher horror killer less inexplicable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's a very good game, with extremely strange mechanics. The problem is that the in-game tutorials are shit, and the mechanics are at times contradictory and counter-intuitive. But it's worth playing for the story, music, and graphics.

Weapons have type, affinities, and class. Learn what these mean from an online guide. Be aware that it'll be impossible to match them up perfectly, and (even if you could) it would be tedious to swap your weapon for every enemy. FYI, type has an outsized role in the damage calculation, affinity is medium, and class is the least. So just focus on type and ignore the others, but you may switch for affinities very rarely if it's a big encounter and you have a great weapon for it.

Read how crafting works online. You MUST craft and you MUST know how combinations work. Drops in chests are shit.

There's an optional dungeon. Get to the end of the first floor and use the item they give you for crafting. It's phenomenal against the final boss.

If you get good stat bonus rolls, stay current with competent crafting, and use the correct type, you'll become OP and finish most end-game boss fights in just a few rounds.

>>9522394

You don't need a guide.
The weapon crafting in this game is similar to demon fusion in SMT games.
The game throws a lot of weapons at you through drops/chests and it's up to you to fuse them into better ones.
You can simply go to a blacksmith's shop and try combining random ones to see what you get.
Some combinations give you a similar weapon, some the same but augmented, some a weapon of a higher tier and some a completely different "type". You can easily experiment with all this on your own and figure it out on the go.

The idea is to upgrade your weapons but keep an eye on the stats so certain ones keep improving etc...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9527020

iirc any weapon can only have one B/E/P and that is the default for that weapon type

Those values might only come into play when you combine stuff so other values carry over since weapons mix and match.
So a secondary non-active type will carry over in value in a future smithing combo where your blunt is turned into an edged, then the 6 from edged that your blunt weapon had will matter

This is why it's important to keep combining weapons and stacking these numbers as you go, and sometimes you'll have to have an intermediate weapon of a different type before you can combine it back into your desired type later on.

Like I said earlier, the best comparison is fusing demons in SMT games. Same as making sure certain spells/moves carry over across many fusions to your desired demon, the same is true here with types and affinities. Once you figure out (through experience) what weapon you're aiming for down the line, you can reverse-chart the necessary weapons to get to it and then optimize the combinations. If you do that you'll get a better resulting weapon than blindly mixing them, but you can clear the game without ever having to resort to that.

Also, there are two releases of Night Trap for the Sega CD. The second release actually improves the colour encoding. The devs at Digital Pictures were not happy with the colour output. They were originally planning on releasing Night Trap on the SNES Playstation add-on, before Sega picked up the publishing for the Sega CD. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9522595
PS2 using ps1 controllers doesn’t mean DualShock 2 = DualShock 1
Ps1 being compatible with PS2 pads also doesn’t make the two controllers the same.

The way the DualShock 2 outputs is just straight up different than how the original pads work. They can however detect when they’re plugged into a ps1 (or ps2 in ps1 mode) and switch into a legacy compatability mode

Most ps2 games will also support the PS1 style controller protocols. But it wasn’t required by Sony later on.
Kingdom hearts 2 for example doesn’t work with DualShock 1s

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9518587
I'd make this top 10
1. Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow—must play for everyone. If you pick just 1 game, make it this one.
2. Rhythm Tengoku—best rhythm game I've played. Play if you like quirky games like Wario Ware and rhythm games.
3. Advance Wars—personally not a fan, but those who liked it spent hundreds of hours in it. Very addictive strategy game.
4. WarioWare—quirky and addictive, one of the more original games for GBA. If you've never tried it, do. If you did, still fun to see where it all started from.
5. Metroid Fusion—it's 2D Metroid, enough said. It's great despite some say it's not Super Metroid.
6. Mother 3—not a perfect RPG, but one many people want to play now. Play if you like Earthbound or want an RPG with plot.
7. Wario Land 4—some praise this is as pinnacle of GBA or even best platformer ever, others will write it off as good but ultimately weaker than the GBC ones. Regardless, well worth a try.
8. Mario & Luigi—actually very good RPG, only brought down by bing bang wahoo style and kinda whatever graphics.
9. Kirbies in general—always fun and worth a play. Play if you like Kirby, don't play if you're sick of platformers.
10. Mega Man Zero 3 & 4—decent games, but got pretty overrated recently as some "official canon classics". I beat them all, they're fun and good but not really masterpieces. Play if you like Mega Man X series and / or have played the other 9 games already.
Not on the list:
SNES ports, especially Mario ports—kind of obsolete in current day and age, maybe save for SMW as you can collect dragon coins in it, but that's it.
Pokemons—you either love them or hate them. If you love them, you probably know which ones to play anyway, and may prefer remakes.
Zelda: Minish Cap—it's more Zelda. Play it or skip it, it's alright if you want more ALTTP but thats about it.
Treasure games—no comment.
Mega Man Battle Network—one of those monster / card collect series that just goes on and on.

Because you're also not pushing the offensive when you have the opening.

The idea behind Guard Crush isn't to punish turtlers, it's to get people to realize that blocking should precede countering. Blocking something then just waiting for the next attack to block that too is pointless and slows the game down. Ideally you want to learn what you can follow a block with.
