I did get a desoldering pump, it was included with the soldering station as well as the solder itself. It's a 60/40 solder which I understand is the most common one. At this point, I would worry to much about the type of solder, the one you buy at the hardware store is going to be just fine, but if you must know, there is a type of solder material that includes flux inside the solder tube. From what I understand, you really want to get some flux so that you can break the oxidation surface in most metallic components and the solder sticks to it properly. I think that is more important.
And as far as removing solder goes, I'm going to use a desoldering pump, but you may also you those desoldering copper braids.

>>9523926
Took forever. Lots of fucking around with one of those dogshit solder suckers and wick. But there were still a few pins that connect to a large ground plain that I just couldnt get free.

I ended up getting it out with a fucking heat gun. I put the board chip-side down against an iron 45lb plate with the PPU over the center hole. I covered the motherboard with several layers of aluminum foil so that only the PPU pins were exposed. Then I heater it up a bit at a time and started tuggging on the PPU from the bottom underneath the iron plate until eventually I tugged it free

I was so scared that I probably just fried the chip... but it worked. Still going strong to this day

I think it depends on what kind of household you grew up in. In my home games were an occasional treat. My dad hated when I got more of them. I grew up not knowing that buying used games was even a thing. So of course I didn't get guide books or magazines either. I would just play games until I got too bored or frustrated to continue. Completing levels felt great but beating the game was not the objective, the objective was to have fun and keep that going.

I never saw the ending to SMB1 and didn't feel it was important to see one. After all, cartoons don't end, they just keep having episodes after episodes, so why should a game have to end? That's bad. Just like if my favorite cartoon ended altogether. My first console was the NES and we got a garage sale Atari and C64 as well. Most of those games had no ending so I thought it was normal.

I remember Commando on NES was probably the first game I ever beat. To me I was just exploring the game, seeing new levels and environments. Then all of the sudden I see the Congratulations screen. I was amazed that this game had an actual ending. I must have been very young because I don't even remember being confused by the horrific engrish on the screen.

Fairly rarely, in fact. Depends on the game. Beatemups are usually easy to clear in a sitting, and RPGs, while they take time, are just a steady grind of getting stronger until you win. There are some games where, as a kid, my bros and I would play for a bit, have fun, then swap cartridges to something else, with some titles remaining perpetually unbeaten. But we were never particularly bothered by it. It sounds like a bizarre thing to say, but "you have to be able to beat it" never felt like a required selling point back in the day. Just trying to get farther for the explorative reward of seeing the next level or the new enemy types was exciting enough. It was fun to be able to go to school the next day and tell kids "dude I got to level 4 once and there's these grey octopus things that shoot missiles!" on some game.

Part of it comes down to ownership vs rental though. It wasn't common for kids in our region and generation to own lots of games, we weren't super rich. So we'd get one or two a year for birthday/Christmas, and borrow them between ourselves. When rentals became a thing it greatly expanded the number of titles we were able to play, and at only 3 days a pop it was common to return a game without clearing it, to try something else, then come back to it and rent it again at a later date (unless it was so awesome that it was worth renting multiple times in a row; when Street Fighter 2 came out on SNES I think we stayed up 25 hours playing that).

I do have some distinct memories of games I did beat, though. Zelda 1 multiple times - always an immersive adventure. Final Fantasy 1 as well, and grinding or no the last dungeon can get tricky if you're not smart with your spellcasting. Castlevania 1, was pretty proud when I could sit down and beat that in a single run. NES Strider, loved the music and anime intro to that (and we wouldn't know what "anime" was for a couple more years)

posts.com:
Beating a game wasn't expected, it was an accomplishment. Most of the games could be beaten in an hour or two if you knew how and had the skills for it. Figuring out what to do and developing the skills needed was what took so much time. Most of the games we played but didn't own were rentals, so you had three days to git gud and go for a win. Very rarely did you beat a rented game and consider it anything other than too easy. Odds are you didn't beat every game you owned either, even though you only got 2-4 new games a year. I never did finish SMB1, always got filtered in World 8 and played something else after. Never cared enough to memorize the last few levels to get through. While BBS's and game guides did exist, the majority of game info came from game magazines and your friends. So if no one you know understands how to get past a specific point and you don't have any magazine with the info, you were usually gonna just be stuck there every time you played the game.
People didn't always get stuck on the hard boss back then, instead people got stuck in strange spots. My cousin was stuck in Legend of Zelda until I showed him where level 8 was hidden. I got stuck in Deja Vu because I couldn't figure out what evidence I needed to dump. I had to show every kid I knew how to finish Tree Tops in Spyro the Dragon, and I only knew about it because of some PS1 demo disc that had an interview with Copeland that showed Spyro going to the distant tree by doing a long charge over the different ramps. No one I knew as a kid could get the good ending in Warhawk, since none of us knew you had to do something special to trigger it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9523212
>Zoomer here
Fuck off and get your own childhood, kid.

>How often or how quickly would you beat games?
It depended on the game, really. I was lucky enough to have cool parents that basically let me have unfettered access to my electronic toys provided I didn't have any other responsibilities. I had a LOT of time to play as a kid (school hours excepted), but some games were just harder than others. Some were surprisingly easy. It took my friends and I just a couple of weeks to finish SMB2, for example. Kirby was pretty easy, too.

On the other hand, it was roughly two years later until I finally managed to finish the original TMNT. Shit was hard. I think I was actually in high school before I managed to finish Bayou Billy. IIRC, Contra ended up coming out in what was basically the middle of the school year for us, and the withdrawal was unbearable. It was like the whole country was desperately waiting to get home, plow through their homework, and then obsessively play Contra until a parent literally tore us away from the television. It wasn't a quick finish, at least not for us, but I think the end screen came faster than it otherwise would have simply because we were all playing it across every bit of free time we had.

It's probably also worth mentioning that a lot of the games considered to be "NES hard" seemed to be the sorts of games that you couldn't rely on collective knowledge to finish. Contra didn't really have any tips to share other than "shoot the boss right when it does X and don't get hit." No Explorer's Handbook included in the game box to tell you where Erdrick's Token was. No issue of Nintendo Power to clue you in about kneeling near a waterfall with a crystal. It was an action game that relied mostly on muscle memory, reflexes, and rote memorization. Those games tended to take longer to finish, at least in my experience.

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Of course, we were also splitting our game time across different platforms, so that affected finish times as well. I had Atari stuff I wasn't willing to part with, including a couple of 2600s, an 800, and a sizable library I still enjoy today. (We obviously played other games when we visited, despite his protests.) My best friend at the time had a Commodore 64 at home we played a lot as well, many a cozy afternoon spent on Raid Over Moscow and Impossible Mission. >>9527925
I found the best compromise between having a session that doesn't go on for forever and skipping over most of the game is to play through and beat the first two worlds and get the whistles, then pick two more worlds from 3-7 to play through and beat, then go for world 8. I personally preferred running through World 4 and 5 the most. World 3 is a ton of underwater levels which suck without a Frog Suit, World 6 is all ice levels but at least gives you access to the Hammer Bros Suit, and World 7 is cool but you'll mostly die due to running out of time due to how maze-like most levels are. World 4 had the cool giant versions of enemies and blocks, and World 5 had the shoe to play with as well as at least one Tanooki Suit to grab. World 5 also gives you a way to generate 99 lives if you are patient enough.
Plus clearing out those four worlds means you'll walk into World 8 with 2 P-Wings(one from letter at end of World 1, other from letter at end of World 4), two Clouds from World 2's letter and World 5's letter, a Frog Suit from World 2, and at least one Tanooki Suit from World 5, plus whatever leaves, flowers, mushrooms, and stars you've managed to collect. Once you hit World 8, you should have a Frog Suit for the ship so you can just swim under the entire level, a P-Wing for the air fleet so you can fly over that mess, and enough power-ups and lives to power through the rest. The second P-Wing can come in handy for any one level that gives you too much stress, or can be used in the final level to fly over the wall and fight the Bowser clone that was never explained.

The narrative/world building aspects were far more advanced than other games of the time, but what really makes it unique is the attention to detail on the life simulation side of things which, to my knowledge, has not been matched to this day. Back in the day I appropriated an abandoned castle, cleared out the cobwebs and rubble and filled it with automatons that I programmed to do chores, brought in a harem of naked women, etc. There's all kinds of crazy stuff you can do in this game, and there has been nothing quite like it since, let alone at the time.

A few years ago I was watching random Game Center episodes, my parents and my brother were out of town so I went to my brother's bedroom intent on smoking some of his weed (I had smoked before). He had some sort of dust in a grinder thing (I have no clue about weed stuff other than just smoking it very occasionally).
I put some weed in the pipe with the dust and smoked, waited half an hour and nothing happened, figured I'd smoked too little and just left it at that, then went to take a shower. I was in the shower for a good half an hour before I realized I was finally high. All the lights hurt, and directly looking at one for a brief moment made my ears feel like I was getting hit with cymbals in the head. All I could do was fall on my bed, cover my face with a pillow and focus on Arino's voice until I felt well enough to get up and turn off the lights. GCCX stood there running with me all night, keeping me safe from my druggie demons.
Thank you Arino-san.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9517751
Unmodded Oblivion is dogshit from a gameplay perspective, anyone who tries to argue otherwise has either not played past level 20 or has not touched the game in 15 years. Barely any feedback compared to the meaty thwack and stagger animations in Morrowind, and bloated HP pools to offset hit chance being removed means you end up with monotonous 5 minute slap fights every two or three minutes. Aggressive level scaling on everything will either have you tearing you hair out trying to keep an edge against enemies in the next bracket ahead of you or constantly throttling the difficulty slider up and down to just be able to play the game without getting reamed by the hundreds of ogres and minotaurs that will eventually spawn in the wilderness. Individual quest premises are usually fun or entertaining, but most of them are not very well realized, and the big quest lines easily have some of the lamest writing and design in the game. The voice acting, endearingly shit NPC AI, and overall comfy atmosphere are Oblivion's saving graces, and I suspect they're the primary reason more people aren't harsher when evaluating it. It really does feel like Bizarro Morrowind sometimes, since almost every issue someone may have with Morrowind is """""fixed""""" by Oblivion, but every problem with Oblivion has a design-level solution that already existed in Morrowind.

>>9517445
I have only played Origins and Shattered Memories and didn't really like either.

Origins:
Pros:
>decent attempt to recapture the feel of the originals
>good atmosphere in a few areas, keeps use of fixed camera angles but they're awkward in a few areas
>brings back outdoor exploration from SH1
>good ost, as expected from Yamaoka
Cons:
>over emphasis on physical combat, made way more annoying then it needs to be because weapons have durability and you can carry unlimited weapons, so if you want a specific weapon you literally have to menu across dozens of weapons you picked up before it
>core mechanic is you can enter and leave the otherworld whenever you wish, this leads to a lot of samey "explore normal world, enter otherworld and interact with something, go back and use the change to the real world to progress" situations. Also it just makes the existence of otherworld in general less memorable
>story is pretty terrible. The game simultaneously tries to do a retread of the lore seen in SH1 and have the protagonist experience his own SH2 journey of self realization and neither comes close to being good. The SH1 characters act nothing like they did in the original making their motives and dialogue awkward and Travis' own story is both very generic and not even executed well
Overall a 6/10, just above average to be notable I would say but lacks the memorable aspects of prior games. as a lorefag the way they recontextualize so many aspects of SH1, from the cast to the lore, really annoys the fuck out of me but that's a more personal problem.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9517721
Shattered Memories:
Pros:
>looks great for a wii game, environments are well detailed and character models look mostly okay beside the faces I would say
>Yamaoka's last game for the series, not his greatest work but there's still some great tracks here
Cons:
>combat has been removed entirely, you have no means to defend yourself to any capacity. This could have been interesting if executed better but then this leads into the next major issue
>enemies only appear in scripted chase sequences. Not only do you spend most of the game with no tension since there's no danger, but even when enemies appear all you do is easily run away from them
>puzzles are terrible. A lot of them try too hard to incorporate the wiimote and feel more like playing some kind of dumb minigame then a thoughtful puzzle you have to think about
>exploration is weak, with no danger normally it's just you traversing linear layouts with little to do
>the "scares" are just from listening to voice messages of teenagers being retarded and putting themselves in dumb situations, they're not scary or even entertaining
>the game big appeal, the way it "psychoanalyzes" you, feels very cheap and literally punishes you for looking at things across the game. What you look at determines what kind of person your Harry is and you basically have "decent human being" and varying levels of him being a shitty person.
4/10. A lot of people seem to quite like this one and I just don't get it. It's not only essentially a walking sim, but a walking sim that punishes you for exploring by changing whatever outcome you may desire. I really don't get what people see in it but still recommend it, maybe you could get something more out of it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9523318
Anon, you got it all wrong.

The original project, Room 302, was always intended to be connected to Silent Hill. It more seems like the connections were going to be very loose though, rather then tie into previous games through the use of elements like Walter and the cult. The real reason it came out wonky was because after SH2 Konami forced Team Silent to develope both SH3 and SH4 simaltaneously. Because if this Team Silent essentially split into two teams, a lot of the more key members went to work on SH3 while the sort of "B-Team" of Team Silent did SH4. A lot of people who did smaller roles in SH1/2 were forced into majpr positions with SH4, resulting in the muddled execution.

>>9524923
>lists the unique properties of the original games

you're a disingenuous little fuck, I could just as easily flip the two and do the same. RE4 is a fantastic action game, it's not trying to be like the original games because the developers were tired of making the same thing over and over so they took it in a bold new direction. you might not like it as a RE game, but you're pants on head retarded if you can't understand its merits
it has a ton of gameplay depth, and the amount of variety and quality of level design, enemy variety, enemy placement and so on is staggering; it constantly throws in new ideas and it's exceedingly rare that one room or area will have the same setup as the ones before it
in terms of gameplay depth:
in RE4 shooting enemies on specific parts of the body can stun them, you can knock them prone, disarm them, stab them, hit projectiles in mid-air, set off explosives if they're holding one, set up a high damage suplex or a roundhouse kick that hits multiple enemies at once, shoot them off ledges
and then there's things like kicking down ladders, vaulting, throwing grenades, jumping through windows, barricading windows and doors, kicking doors open to hit enemies
plus there's obviously all of the different guns, the attachments for said guns, the grenades, the level design itself, the enemy variety, how the locations are constantly changing, the gimmick stuff like the boat fight, the minecart etc
if I was a disingenuous worm like you I might say that all you do in the original games is 'aim' (aiming is automatic) and bang bang bang
anyway, obviously the game is fantastic in other areas, namely atmosphere, the careful balance it treads between B-movie and more serious and tense moments, the pacing, the replayability, the amount of content on offer etc
RE4 is Good Game Design: The Game

>>9526145
I don't find the challenge provided by platforming to be very interesting. Challenging combat sections are interesting because you have options, you can change up your approach or what sub-weapon you want to use at that point in the game (depending on availability) and you can play more or less aggressively depending on your health. Platforming is either you press a button at the right time or you don't. Punishing that failure with death makes the game more challenging, yes, but it doesn't make it any more interesting or fun. In fact, it can make it more boring.

Compare phase one of Dracula in X to phase one in Rondo, for example. The fact that the Dracula X fight is full of instant-kill death pits means that the smartest approach is to camp in one spot and move as minimally as possible. That means you spend a good chunk of the fight sitting twiddling your thumbs waiting for Dracula to show up, and no matter how much health you have, or how much health Dracula's at, it's never safe to get more aggressive and jump around looking for him because the pits kill you instantly. Is it harder than the Rondo Dracula fight? Absolutely. Is it more boring? Absolutely.

Playing aggressively during the first phase doesn't pay because Dracula's spawn points are completely random. So either way, whether you move or don't, you have the same ammount of chance of him spawning next to you but if moving that has the added effect of finding yourself in a more dangerous situation.

With that said, that is the whole point of the fight, it's an endurance/patience test, in which if you know what you're doing you very likely will never get hit, but if you're a clueless impatient ADHD ridden kid, you're gonna get fucked and keep dying from a single hit. It rewards discipline, and there are still many things to learn to "get good" during that first phase even if you stay put.

>Sega started demanding changes to the game (like changing the character designs and adding a "rival") to appeal the westerners which were the primary 32X audience; meanwhile, Konami soon realized without a CD-addon that porting Rondo to cartridge was ridiculous.
>Midway through development it became clear that the path forward was to make a new game sharing Rondo assets if it couldn't live up to the original vision.
>For a fuller return on investment, Konami cuts losses with the dodgy Sega addon and focuses B-team on the more popular Super Nintendo while A-team moves on to bigger and better things like Symphony of the Night.
"But The Bloodletting!" I imagine you saying. To dispel that notion, "Castlevania: The Bloodletting" was a vague listing that Konami had for a PlayStation and Saturn game around the same time, which sounds a lot like the period of development where Symphony was a Bloodlines sequel rather than a Rondo one. It was never the 32X game.

>>9505037
Depends. Fighting games generally have an arcade mode that has you fight AIs but older especially tend to have hard ones, especially if you play the arcade versions. Some fighting games also have difficulty settings in the options, which could help to ease you in, depending on the game.
I'm far from an expert, but speaking personally, I found that Soulcalibur and Capcom vs SNK helped me quite a bit: SCI gives you a decent amount of moves to do through buttons and directionals rather than inputs and the Groove system in Capcom vs SNK was what pushed me to learn how inputs work (although getting to Akuma was next to impossible for me until I got lucky). The A.I. in CvS1 can be hard if it gets in the mood though (Ryu in particular is a pain in the ass, but still doable if you aren't worrying about Groove too much).

>>9494516
I don't find fighting games a lot of fun to play in single player desu, I think it's because they rely so much on reading your opponent and trying not to get read yourself, and that element just doesn't really exist against a CPU beyond figuring out their rudimentary pattern. You can't mix up a CPU, and whether you block their mix-up can come down to pure luck whereas against a human it's not ALL luck, even if it's unreactable. If enemies in single-player action games had unreactable mix-ups it'd be considered pure BS and that's what you're dealing with sometimes when playing against CPUs. It's like playing poker against a computer, it feels kinda pointless.

Although doing combos against CPUs can be fun, since in most fighting games once you begin a combo the game essentially becomes a single-player rhythm game until the combo ends. Fighting games are a weird genre.

>>9526440
Some time in the mid to late 2010s or whenever the fuck, a lot of character designs and whatnot of Mario characters started standardized, most notably Toads and certain enemies. While it's unclear if it is part of the mandate or just Nintendo being lazy/formulamatic, Mario games also followed a general theme structure that was rarely broken (grasslands first, desert second, beach third, etc).
The "Mario mandate" aspect mostly comes from the RPGs, primarily Paper Mario Sticker Star, where the team were told to not to make any new characters (Kersti being the lone exception). Some comments made around the time of Origami King's release suggest that this clause is still in affect in some way, with new characters needing to be very distinct. This standardization also carried on throughout other RPGs where the more distinct and out there Toad designs have been dropped, although NPC variety tends to be a slightly better due to using mooks/Yoshis as well as Toads.
Basically, all of this cemented Miyamoto as a control-freak mad man hellbent on removing the "soul" from the series. Whether or not he actually is in reality is up for debate.

They likely do, but wouldn't be relevant due to most Nintendo series being done in-house and having more consistency compared to the Mario games.

You really just need to look at Castlevania 64's contemporaries to see where everything went wrong.

>Super Mario 64
>Ocarina of Time
>Final Fantasy 7
>Metal Gear Solid
>F-Zero X
>Star Fox 64

In a generation where virtually every 2D series worth their salt was making a successful transition to 3D, Castlevania fucked up massively. Even Legacy of Darkness couldn't fix it. People love to go on about its atmosphere these days, but back then, the game looked, played, and sounded like shit compared to everything around it. Worse, CV64 was one of the WORST games in the series at the time, released after Symphony of the Night showed what a modern Castlevania could look like in 2D. 64 failed on every meaningful level to deliver that same quality in 3D.

I hate that people like this game now. I really do.

If you're into Bubble Bobble and arcade-style games, check out Parasol Stars. It's a neat little game, and AFAIK plays best on the PCE. Only reason I know of it is because my friend and his gf showed up at my house with a big bin full of games (they were the gf's brother's, who left them when he moved out), including a TG-16 and a couple of games for it, which none of us had ever played. My bud's gf fell absolutely in love with it (she got really good at it, too), and we took turns playing it until we beat it, then replayed it several times until we got the best ending.

I've only really played a few other games for it since then, but I've been meaning to explore it further. I like how a lot of its games look and feel like souped-up, highly colorful NES games, and once you factor the PCE-CD games, it's even better. Unlike the Sega CD, it appears to have had a nice amount of high quality titles worth playing.

>original arcade game ported to ps1 - the normalcy ends here
>arcade and console series immediately split into two for some reason

>3rd game on arcades never goes to console, and it's called....RAVE racer
>ps1 gets a 2nd game, and it's different from rr2, called ridge racer revolution
>ps1 gets a 3rd game, again separate from the arcade rave racer, and it's called....RAGE racer
>ps1 gets a 4th game, again unique from the arcades, called...R4: ridge racer type 4
>the series cheats on playstation and gets an N64 release randomly
>the series at this point suddenly pivots from being a playstation stalwart franchise to a mercenary franchise hopping from one console launch title to another
>ridge racer v (we're suddenly doing roman numerals) is a launch title for ps2, and also an arcade game, the first unification of console and arcade since RR1, and also the last time this happens. also there was never a 4th arcade game.
>ridge racer ds is a port of ridge racer 64 and is an exclusive launch title for the nds
>ridge racer (yep, no unique name, just ridge racer) is an exclusive launch title for psp. it gets better - the name in japan is ridge racers (plural)
>ridge racer 2 (again, ridge racers 2 in japan) releases on psp, using the same name as the unrelated ridge racer 2 arcade
>ridge racer 6 (goodbye roman numerals, we hardly knew ye) is an exclusive launch title for x360
>ridge racer 7 is an exclusive launch title for ps3
>ridge racer 3d is an exclusive launch title for 3ds
>ridge racer (whoops, we're using this name for the 3rd time now) is an exclusive launch title for psvita
>the psvita game is panned and at this point the series dies and completely falls apart
>ridge racer unbounded is the last main release in 2012 and has nothing to do with any prior entries
>the series gets relegated to multiple mobile shovelware releases that nobody cares about - 3 of the 4 don't even have wikipedia entries
>series dies in 2016

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
OP bothered me that much I'm going to briefly summarise the flow and design of each level in Einhander as a counter argument.

>Stage 1
>Metropolis background, moving billboards, neon signs can be destroyed, battle amongst skyscrapers, branching path leads to former city underground with unexploded warhead, final section takes place along highway

>Stage 2
>Wasteland stage, involves following an armoured train, train has multiple moving parts, some of which are destructible, action shifts from foreground to background, final section takes place in cave

>Stage 3
>Large vertical shaft inside industrial facility as play field whilst game still functions on horizontal field, broken up by Boss battle, returns to a vertical section with a lowering destructible ceiling that deploys enemies, stage continues horizontally, final section is in room that rotates according to Boss' weight

>Stage 4
>Stage introduces water with reflective surfaces and skimming effects, marine enemies appear, perspective changes to display Boss swimming underwater, proceeds to branching routes with moving elevators, final section includes destructible background and Boss battle takes place on surface after breaching

>Stage 5
>Spaceport stage with indoor and outdoor sections after the previous two stages taking place fully indoors, Boss is shown lurking behind background before battle, destructible background elements, final section takes place on climbing runway

>Stage 6
>Takes place entirely in the sky in which the objective is to destroy the rocket that has been launched within the time limit, Boss battle then takes place above the atmosphere, hidden Boss included

>Stage 7
>Space stage with turbulent movement to simulate effects of combat in space, assisted by lighting, enemies explode in different directions accordingly, Final Boss incorporates this with additional whirling camera

Not to mention the way each stage has its own atmosphere and various unique features.

>Neither is correct. Each game follows its own rules.
Zero lives is better. If you get down to 1 life, and you've never played the game before, you don't know if you are about to game over or if you have one remaining life. But when you reach zero lives, you know that when you die you will definitely game over. So zero lives is clearer.

What about continues? That becomes clearer. Every time you use a continue, your continues decrement by 1. This means when you have 1 continue remaining you can continue one more time. Very clear and easy to understand. So why make lives inconsistent with continues? It would be nonsensical to do so.

>LIVES: 1

I have one life left. If I die, I will be on my last life. I will have zero lives remaining. Presently I have one life remaining, but if I die I will have zero.

>LIVES: 0

I have no more lives, thus if I die, it will be game over. If I had 1 life remaining, it would not be game over, because I would have one life. But if I died on that life, I would have zero. If I have zero lives and I die, it is game over.

Close. Stenzek was providing an official Duckstation core, only it was closed-source (which actually violates its GPL license). However, he got into several spats with the libretro team (mostly with Twinaphex, who's similarly caustic) and ended up fucking off and ceased working on the Duckstation core or providing support for it. As a result, they decided to create a fork called Swanstation, and Stenzek went on to make claims about it using "stolen code from his private repo" for which he never provided any proof, and it all came to a head when he found out about a cloud gaming service known as Piepacker that was using Swanstation for PS1 emulation, which was reported to have made a few million in profits, and that it was employing a libretro contributor at the time. He went absolutely nuclear over all this, and he ended up conflating all these things together and made up a narrative that the libretro team was making millions off of his stolen code, and used it as an excuse to cease working on Duckstation altogether, which then pissed off dicksuckers in Reddit, Twitter and Resetera, who promptly attempted to cancel libretro and RetroArch. The effort lasted all of a week, especially once enough people began poking holes in Stenzek's MUH STOLEN CODE narrative and screenshots of his own shit behavior made the rounds.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9521549

They're zoomer retards, it's that simple, don't try to reason with them.

They think they are "recreating" the "effect" of a CRT screen, but that's not what they are doing, and unless they have a HDR 8K monitor that's barely even possible. Let alone on the garbage 10 year old 1080P panel they probably use them on.

The annoying thing is, filters are not a meme; but the real function is to simply break the image up. That's what a REAL CRT does. It's a form of natural anti-aliasing, it's an optical illusion that tricks your eye into thinking the pixels blend together. If people were making filters that did this without trying to replicate a CRT we would probably have vastly superior filters.

Personally I just use a 50% opaque scanline filter, and increase brightness to compensate, making sure the line integer matches the internal rendering resolution. When I play from sofa distance I can't see the lines, it just looks like a smooth image instead. It's not as perfect as a real CRT but it's better than the eye-strain inducing garbage of "CRT filters".

Stretched graphics annoy me, but so do inconsistent pixel heights that result from some programs' aspect ratio corrections (e.g. ScummVM), and interpolation or whatever is better but I still notice it and then can't un-see it. Well yeah. I don't need them to be squares; all of the pixels being 5x6 is fine. The problem was 16:10-to-4:3 correction on less-than-1600x1200 displays being implemented as a mess of different pixel heights. Really I notice it most in ScummVM subtitles and sometimes cursors.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
On a CRT you'd just use the monitor controls to adjust the vertical height of the image.
On a lot of 320x200 games most people were actually playing in 640x400 at the time of release so they would have clearly seen individual pixels on an RGB VGA monitor.

Play these games at the highest resolution possible and the pixel distortion will be minimized.
Yes, you should use a CRT filter. But tweaked to resemble an RGB PC CRT monitor.

a shader that would upscale to multiples of 5x6 using nearest-neighbour and then downscale to your display res using bilinear should be mandatory on every source port, retro game engine, reverse engineering project...

and then upscale to 3200x2400 when using up to 4K displays

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9527958
I'm not sure how most implement it, but I think ScummVM's default settings will first upscale by 2x or whatever, then increase height by 20%, and then scale to screen resolution if fullscreen is enabled. It ends up looking a bit poopy unless you either use the Normal 5x scaler to get 5x5 pixels before the 20% height increase. There's also an even-pixels scaler option for the OpenGL renderer, which ensures all pixels are the same size by compromising on the exact pixel aspect ratio, e.g. it might do 5x4 pixels to scale to 1280x1000 on a 1080p screen -- which is kind of interesting but still not ideal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There's this quirk with Megaman 4-6 where the charging sound won't play under certain conditions, like, if the channel is busy playing something else at the moment when the charging sound should start playing. You can achieve this for example, by letting go of a charge then pressing the button again right after, if you time and aim it right, you'll start charging when the channel is busy playing the hit/explosion sound and you'll get a silent charge that lasts until you let go. Lately when I do buster only replays of those games I try to time my shots to get silent charges as much as I can, so I can enjoy the music more. It's a fun little diversion from just playing the regular way.

I believe the channel also gets muted during screen transitions so you can time it with those too? I don't know all the details to be honest, but I wonder if any of those autists that like to dissect game code have ever figured out the exact conditions during which this happens, would be fun to know.

>>9520615
Not who you're replying to, but beyond its greater damage output, the charge shot also has a wider hitbox (after MM4) and doesn't allow you to fire any lemons until it leaves the screen. As such, there are more than a few situations where not starting off with a charge shot is the better play:
>Groups of weak, vertically-stacked enemies
>Bosses with unpredictable vertical movement (laying down a 'spread' of lemons gives you better odds of hitting them)
>Enemies with small weak points
>Enemies that have to be 'revealed' (like the barrels from MM6) before becoming vulnerable
>Enemies that you have to repel by firing shots at their invulnerable points (think the gorilla midboss from MM6)

The main issue here is that several games in the series deliberately avoid these kinds of situations, instead promoting gameplay where the charge shot is always the ideal option. MM5 is particularly bad about this - almost every stage includes low-lying enemies that can only be hit with charge shots, and the stage layout gives you ample time to prepare shots in between enemy waves.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9517761
>What about link cable support on GB/C/A games? Can you demonstrate this feature while paired with an original console? No!

For the GB/GBC, yes. The cores support it over the SNAC connection and there are SNAC cables for it.

For GBA currently no, the core does not support it yet, but the hardware is capable if the core got updated to support it.

>What about utilizing custom chips on cartridges to expand features on consoles?

It currently supports every expansion chip except those two SNES Mahjong games that had ARM co-processors on them. It even supports the SPC-7110 games, something not even SNES flashcarts support, and the homebrew "custom" SNES expansion chips like the MSU-1 or the additional custom hardware in the Atari 7800 version of Rikki and Vikki, of which only a single software emulator is able to run.... and only because the developer of the game made that emulator specifically to run his game on PCs.

>>9521590
Input lag can definitely be a perceptible problem, but there's both people who dramatically oversell its existence, prominence, and impact, as well as those trying to pretend that it's actually nothing.
In truth, input lag can vary widely for a very large amount of different reasons, given how different games work differently, different displays work differently, and different software emulators and hardware emulators differ amongst each other as well as original hardware, along with potential settings, there's hundreds of variables determining what kind of input lag you can be looking at. In many cases it truly isn't perceptible, others may be subtly perceptible, and some where it has an appreciable impact on the player's experience without them having to be a turbo-autistic speedrunner who can do arbitrary code execution in their sleep.
It's cumulative.

https://youtu.be/b3tbcUszA2s?t=515

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9521749
I appreciate what the section of the video you linked demonstrates which justifies some of my own research and adds merit to what people have taught me from different retro gaming communities. This is why I am really interested in the MiSTer and frequently visit my locals to play the one they set up since I can't afford my own yet. The FPGA itself doesn't have any lag; and disregarding how accurate the core is, so the program gets sent out as is. Further down the pipeline is where the potential accumulative lag begins to be introduced.

>Input Device
You can either use the direct serial port to interface original hardware via SNAC. Direct serial has no inherent lag, but even an OEM controller might have some, yet not enough that you won't notice. USB on the other hand has to translate your inputs at the OS level which might add delay but nowhere near half a frame so it is up to you to choose a device that has an encoder with the least amount of delay.

see:
MiSTer Input Latency Database [full detailed sheet linked on the page]
https://rpubs.com/misteraddons/inputlatency

>Game itself
Some games have a different kind of delay due to how the programmer affixed the sprite flow and input command as well as other underlying programming variables which might cause undesirable performance. Some of these inconsistencies can be fixed or changed by the community as needed.

>Display
In my opinion, playing over a CRT display is the optimal way to play the MiSTer. There are plenty of options that will suit people of all budgets. As for digital displays, you have an abundance of choice and you will get the best results with a "gaming" monitor designed to provide the least amount of lag.

Or, you can just buy each console you want to play for peace of mind that you are experiencing the game as originally intended.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525380
>Who is the target audience for the mister?
The mistake a lot of people make is that they view the MiSTer FPGA project like a commercial product (i.e Analogue) when in fact it's just an enthusiast venture. The only people making immediate profit off of the project are the people selling pre-built add-ons for the DE-10 Nano to be used with the MiSTer FPGA project, and of course Terasic for each DE-10 Nano unit sold. Sorg, the main developer, is not directly profiting off this project, but he does accept donations which is a huge difference from providing services for pay. Some add-on sellers do state on their website that a portion of each sale will be donated to Sorg so this kind of transparency shows which sellers we should be buying from as well if you don't plan to build your own add-ons.

Most vocal people in the "just emulate for free" category don't actually provide any solid arguments or convincing points to add weight to their posts so I would prefer to disregard them.

There is a surprising amount of people in the MiSTer FPGA community who already have hardware collections and are convinced they can sell parts of their collections with no regrets. The biggest contributing factors to why most haven't pulled the trigger is sentimental value as well as trying to hold on for huge returns in the collector's market. As for people who do have hardware collections plus a CRT and aren't interested in the MiSTer, they are fine where they are because they are not in search of a solution to replicate what they can already do now.

>Has anyone tried out the AO486 core?
It's in the middleground between setting up real hardware and virtual machines as far as involvement goes, but it's a lot closer to setting up a virtual machine. I have not used external accessories besides mouse and keyboard, but I believe it does support Real-Time Clock and definitely MIDI.

The casual/mainstream market never sees value in specialized hardware, they're too obsessed with convenience and abundance to care about the benefits. Most casuals don't want to have the headaches of worrying about things like accuracy or input timing and are quick to dismiss any discrepancies they think are irrelevant, they just need the game to run and that's it. Software emulation and MiSTer may be visually difficult to distinguish under several circumstances to the average person such as color output or ability to render the game in sync with everything else. The line can be tough to draw for most on which is better because the FPGA-based emulators have quickly caught up and even exceeded it's cycle accurate software counterparts in many technical areas. For any applicable cores, MiSTer has more accurate sound (certified against MDfourier). Most importantly, no core has input delay that isn't native to the original game or hardware, something all software emulators still haven't nailed down without the use of run-ahead (banned on speedrun). Input delay is always a subject easily dismissed by the typical casual because you're not practicing a game enough to begin to care about getting optimal input timings in, you just need to play your game and that's it. If you're only concerned that the game runs as best as it could outside of using original hardware, I don't see why having all these options for different budgets hurts.

posts.com:
I use a modchip, but I've also been using it since before ODEs and pseudosaturn were a thing. So I'm not sure if it's still the 'best' option. But if you go that route, you'll still want to get a 4-in-1 AR cart for all the other features.

modchip is incredibly easy to install. It's just a small board that goes in-between the connection to the disc drive. The only thing you need to solder is a 5v cable to the power rail. And even that you can even get away with not actually soldering it, and just twisting it tightly around the rail. That's what I did as a "temporary measure" when I was in college and told myself I'd properly solder it in when I got home. That was over a decade ago and I haven't bothered reopening the system because it Just Werks.

posts.name: Crystal Warriors
posts.com:
This a neat little game. It's a strategy RPG like Shining Force with an RPS elemental system, but when two units attack each other it turns into a mini Wizardry-style turn based battle. Each unit gets two turns, so can choose to retreat and give up your turn if the situation is unfavorable. There's also monsters you can recruit during battles which are useful for compensating for elemental advantages (e.g. a Fire type unit could use a Water type monster).

You recruit characters between rounds and there's even permadeath. It's not too difficult but can punish mistakes pretty hard.

Ms. Pac-Man is pretty important to the series.
It was the first official sequel to Pac-Man, it established Pac-Man's status as a family man, its the only game in the series to be anywhere close to the success and recognizability of the original, the character was frequently used afterwards and even got two more of her own games.

>>9522563
There is literally a huge oversight in the level design. If you go into the last challenge room to get the gold key, if your water is up you need to drain it down by the end of the room. So essentially you clear the challenge, realize you're stuck, have to backtrack and drain the water at the start of the hub area, and do the challenge room again. You literally have no way of knowing how the water is supposed to be before you enter this room, and it's easier to get into the room if the water is raised. Either I'm missing some indication or it's a big fuckup. I doubt the devs were being cruel on purpose.
Not only that, in the saturn version, one of the silver keys is over a grey texture in a pretty incospicuous place, I passed over it 3 times before I was able to notice it, and I only did it because the camera was clipping through the floor and it gave it some contrast. And I was playing in RGB through SCART, lord knows how tough it is to see with a composite signal.
The cistern is no masterpice, but it could be if they fix these wrinkles.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9527523
The first one or the second one? I think the first one is harder. Always keep him at the edge of your screen so he can't reach you with the fire even if he suddenly decides to move towards you, and double jump to hit him twice every time. If he's about to shot the laser it's better to wait, if he's almost off screen chances are he'll shoot the laser straight ahead and miss you, but sometimes it doesn't work so you're better off not jumping until he's done. Oh and you better have the golden armour equipped because otherwise the bracelet has pathetic range and it's weaker too. The green boss is much easier, he only shoots fire at his feet so that should never hit you, except when he gets to the edge of the platform, in that case just back away and wait. The superlaser is also easy to avoid, just be careful when he stops shooting fire and might shoot the laser and duck.

I remember being on the NeoGAF forums in 2003 and reading the flame wars between the Sonyfanbots and Nintendodoids (or whatever they were called) around the PSP and DS. Sony announced the PSP first. Then Nintendo made an announcement that they were making a new handheld that would have two screens, shortly after. Which lead to a lot of speculation. Before both systems were released, people thought that Sony was going to crush Nintendo in the handheld market. But it turned out to be the opposite, as the DS dominated, and the PSP still sold really well. Because the GBA really was selling well with a lot of third party support, Nintendo made that 'the DS will be out third pillar" comment. In the end, the GBA still sold well alongside the DS and DS having backwards compatibility with the GBA helped a lot. People were buying GBA games for their DS.

posts.com:
As far as I know Nintendo's handhelds always did really well for them. They iterated a lot on the hardware. Even the GameBoy Color wasn't really a platform of its own--it was the umpteenth version of the GameBoy. If anything, for the relatively short cycle of its life as the most current Nintendo handheld, it sure had a lot of longevity, success, and a big library of good games.

It seems silly to say this but technology was advancing so rapidly then, in such an immediately noticeably way. It seemed amazing to have something akin to the SNES in your pocket and then in only a few years the DS and the PSP were just shy of their console counterparts, for the most part. No doubt helped by the screen size.

Now Nintendo has no second pillar, but what they have produced is likely on its way to becoming the best selling game console of all time. But I do wonder if they would ever introduce another pillar, a separate and distinct hardware. I'm assuming the next thing will be a close iteration of the Switch though.

desu I was in the same boat. I was 14 when DS released, of course I didn't know much about vidya market back then. I pulled the trigger on buying DS when PSP was still up and coming. turned out PSP would cost much cheaper then I expected and I really regretted not getting it at first.
if you remember the early days of DS, it was pretty lame. SM64 and WarioWare was all that I played. but then it suddenly started getting lots of cool games, like MK64, Osu!, NSMB, Castlevanias, Pokemon, etc.. and on the other hand, PSP suddenly turned out not quite great, with lower effort versions of PS games like MGS, Silent Hill, etc..
it felt crazy to me, but not only DS didn't get steamrolled, but it exploded in popularity and somehow btfod PSP in almost every region.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9520750
>I honestly hadn’t personally heard the term smart phone before Apple’s iPhone came to the market.
I can see that happening. Around 2001–2004 I was reading a lot of mobile tech mags, so I was used to seeing the term "smartphone" everywhere. But if you asked some random guy, he might have said "never heard that word". It wasn't that popular outside of its bubble, at least nowhere near current day level when everyone and their mom have had smartphones for years. Mostly tech-savvy types with used those, and those who clearly had some cash to afford them. PDAs were even more rare (at least where I lived), plenty people didn't know they existed, and few had one.
>We are sort of stuck in this stagnant time for phones without any major innovations what so ever. It’s bizarre.
The truth is, you can only invent something once. Like you can't just invent Wi-Fi again, or frontal phone camera again.
But in the 90–2000s, there were a lot of new tech advances, some fundamentally new things, like e.g. Wi-Fi—they just weren't popularized yet. And we had a whole new transition of old tech going digital, mobile, and wireless—digital cameras, digital media storage, 3G, etc. And once more, you can't just "transition to digital" again—it happened once, and that's it.
A lot of the tech that iPhone introduced wasn't exactly "new", it had been floating around for years. It simply got mature enough for mass market around late 2000s–early 2010s. Kind of like how VR had been around since forever, but got truly big only in recent years.
But sooner or later, you implement all of those ideas that were "floating around". The competition all copies each other and there's not much new to introduce. You basically use up all the innovations that had accumulated for decades.
So yeah, phones have been stagnating. But that's just because the "transition to digital" is largely over, it has been done, perfected, and now it's just marginal improvements.

Also, to add, in many things we've reached the point where "enough is enough" in phones.
There used to be a race for screen size, but then everyone realized that going over 6 inches screen is retarded. The DPI race is also over, because frankly, the difference between Full HD phone and 4k phone is negligible. Phone cameras still do improve, but the megapixel race is also kinda over. Going thinner and lighter is not really impressive anymore. Processors and graphics? You already have pretty damn strong CPUs in phones, considering most people use them only to play cookie clickers, and many phone games look about as good as console ones. Hell, I think Apple was the first company ever to use 5-nm chips in their tech. Storage? Stopped being a problem with 128gb phones becoming the norm. Internet? 4G already offers 100-300mbps on paper, that's more than enough in the era of streaming.
Then again, in other things we're just simply stuck (kinda). Batteries haven't really gotten that much better, they just get bigger with phones, and it's not like we ever got 10x more charge in them in recent years—hence why battery life is still often shit. 5G is coming, but it will need time to roll out, and not like it's going to get cheaper—perhaps the opposite.

>>9516995
>AI's getting better, soon we won't need to learn Japanese,
It's really not. It appears like it is because the end result is usually correct English, but the quality of the translation itself is still really really bad. I have to translate some stuff from Japanese to English for my work before the new year rolls around (I'm not a translator, but I'm the only person in the company who is bilingual enough to do translation so I sometimes get stuck translating stuff) and I thought I could cheese it and run everything through DeepL since it's all super straightforward and grammatically correct with no slang or anything. Simple business language. Fucking nope, errors everywhere and I ended up having to actually translate it all myself. I was really disappointed because I was hoping that I could finish early with machine translation and then read a book or something but I'm pretty sure my ass would be in hot water if I turned in what DeepL gave me.

Btw, a ton of official translations (fan and official) are done by machines these days and that's a big part of why they're so bad, because machine translation is awful and the actual "translator" doesn't actually know the language so they're incapable of catching the mistakes when they happen.

Anyone who is actually fluent in Japanese and English would know that machine translation still has an extremely long way to go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As someone who's followed the fan translation scene since the late '90s, which were focused on very well known titles (in those circles at the time) that just never made it overseas, like FFV and Star Ocean (the latter of which was hilariously controversial especially because DeJap blueballed everyone by claiming the lead translator's HD blew up back in 2001 or 2002 and asked for money lmao), I don't believe learning Japanese just to play video games is worth it especially in this day and age, mostly for a number of reasons.

Unless you specifically consume only Japanese media daily and use it proactively, you're not going to truly learn and comprehend the language and cultural history behind it, especially one that's so wildly different from English. That's not even getting into issues like nonsensical location jokes and references / skits that are extremely dated. There are lots of translators today, both by people who do it for a living or for fun or even AI / MTLs are getting in on the action, all of which pretty much renders that original "worth learning" part moot. On top of that, that's not even getting into the nightmare of localizations and the script purity question. Even with all of those compounded factors, there are people who still pushed through with it and there's a ton more people who know Japanese now than there was a decade or two ago, leaving a very saturated field of translators who are constantly fighting over rights to translate. There's also another thing in this thread that's worth pointing out too: most of the titles posted are either Sega Saturn, obscure PC-E or PS1/PS2 titles, the reason which is that the technology to actually inject and rewrite text, make sure it fits the boxes, etc. is a much more difficult task than translating the script itself wholesale. This is not even a new thing either, since you can find entire script translations on GameFaqs from the 90s and 00s long before the games even had working translation patches.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9523219
Linda Cube Again and Linda Cube Kanzenban are fifth gen remakes of the PC Engine CD title Linda Cube. A "psycho thriller and hunting RPG," protagonist Ken Challenger is chosen, along with his slightly crazy but devoted tomboy girlfriend Linda, to collect one male and one female of every species of animal on the planet of Neo-Kenya and upload them into a massive space ark before a giant meteorite destroys the planet and everything left on it in seven in-game years. As time passes, the weather and seasons change, and various animals and NPCs will only come out during certain conditions. The game features several novel systems, including dog party members which cannot be directly controlled. It also features three unique story scenarios which represent adjoined worlds and excellent art design from Japanese artist Cannabis. The first two scenarios are very violent and dramatic and the third is a joke scenario where everyone gets a happy ending.

>>9523268
Daikoukai Jidai 2 AKA Uncharted Waters: New Horizons, is a fifth gen remake of the cult classic Koei game, a pseudo-historical swashbuckling RPG which takes place during the Age of Exploration. Players can choose to play one of 6 different protagonists which feature different gameplay styles and intertwining storylines. The game has updated graphics and sound compared to the original console releases, which were also sadly censored when initially released in the West. It has an excellent score by Yoko Kanno and an unprecedented amount of freedom in how you approach playing the game, where the world map is a map of the original world.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9523320
Daikoukai Jidai Gaiden is a direct sequel/spinoff to Uncharted Waters: New Horizons. It only features two protagonists, allegedly so that they could go further in-depth with the storylines. It features extensive cameos from the original cast. One of the protagonists, Salvador, is the son of Khayr Ad-Din, AKA Redbeard, king of the corsairs and a major antagonist in the first game. His storyline gets much darker than those of the six protagonists in part two. The game features updated an updated tide and weather system which is meant to be more accurate than the previous game. Islamic regions will also not let you pray in their churches anymore, and Chinese ports are closed off to outsiders in an attempt to be more historically accurate. The coverart is by some famous furfag.

Cyber Doll is a yellow label (soft 18+) RPG for the Sega Saturn. Humans begin to fall apart and are forced to become cyborgs if they want to live. The game features cyberpunk imagery and an excellent soundtrack. The novel combat system features targeted combat where you can shoot out various parts of your cyborg foes, as well as a distance system where different weapons can only be used at certain distances. It features designs by Yasushi Nirasawa, famous for his work on Kamen Rider.

Wolkenkratzer is a 3D fighting rogue-lite game. A unique idea that has not been explored much since, you climb a tower fighting a random enemy from a certain tier on each floor. After you defeat each enemy, you can search the floor for loot, although there is a chance you will have to fight another enemy instead of successfully finding anything.
